questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis?

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEq/L

questions.solution:
Patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) can present with hypokalemia and not hyperkalemia.

Excess production of sweat in CF leads to a significant loss of chloride ions from the extracellular fluid (ECF). The depletion of chloride from the ECF causes an intracellular shift of potassium and activation of renin-aldosterone system, leading to hypokalemia.

The excessive depletion of sodium chloride in CF also affects the acid-base balance. It leads to increased reabsorption of bicarbonate by the kidneys through the chloride-bicarbonate exchanger on the intercalated cells. This process is known as contraction alkalosis (option D) and results in hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis.

Cystic fibrosis, also known as mucoviscidosis, is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. This gene is responsible for encoding ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells, which regulate the flow of ions across various epithelial membranes in the body, including sweat glands, respiratory airways, and pancreatic ducts. The defect in CFTR leads to elevated salt concentrations in sweat and the production of thick, viscous secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Diagnostic tests for CF include the sweat chloride test (option A), where an increased chloride concentration (>60 mEq/L) is considered diagnostic. Immunoreactive trypsinogen levels (option B) are also measured for newborn screening, as they tend to be elevated in CF. Genetic testing for CFTR gene mutations is considered the gold standard and should be performed for all suspected cases. In equivocal cases, nasal transepithelial potential difference can be estimated as an additional diagnostic test.

The criteria for diagnosis is the presence of clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or a positive newborn screening or a sibling with cystic fibrosis, along with evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene (two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or an abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference).

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemical markers would be positive in a patient with adenocarcinoma lung?
questions.solution:
Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1), mucin, and napsin-A are positive in adenocarcinoma lung.

TTF-1 is required for normal lung development. It can be used to distinguish primary adenocarcinoma of the lungs (TTF-1 positive) from other histological types of lung cancers, metastatic adenocarcinoma, and mesothelioma (TTF-1 negative).

P40 and P63 are the markers for squamous cell carcinoma.

Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.

The Lung Cancer Awareness Month, marked in countries across the world every November, in an effort to improve the outcomes for lung cancer patients across the world.

questions.text: Gamma camera is used for _____.

choices.text: To image radioactivity emitted from organs

questions.solution:
Gamma camera is used to image the radioactivity emitted from organs.

This technique is called scintigraphy. Patients undergoing nuclear medicine testing emit ionising radiation. Gamma camera detects this radiation and converts it into an image.

This is used in various scintigraphie such as hepatobiliary scintigraphy, renal scintigraphy and ventilation-perfusion scintigraphy. They are also used in imaging modalities for breast cancer, prostate cancer, various PET and SPECT scans, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs require dosage adjustment during radiotherapy to prevent radiation toxicity?
questions.solution:
Dactinomycin requires dosage adjustment during radiotherapy to prevent radiation toxicity.

Dactinomycin, bleomycin, etc., act through free radical damage just like radiotherapy and may potentiate the effects of radiation. Hence, the dose needs to be adjusted.

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: Band shaped keratopathy is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Band shaped keratopathy is not seen in sickle cell anemia.

Band shaped keratopathy is an abnormality of the cornea characterized by the precipitation of calcium salts in Bowman’s layer in a band-like distribution across the central cornea. It leads to decreased vision, foreign body sensation, and ocular irritation.

It most commonly occurs

  • Secondary to chronic corneal diseases
  • Elevated serum calcium or phosphate
  • Systemic diseases:
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Hyperparathyroidism
    • Vitamin D toxicity,
    • Metastatic neoplasm to bone,
    • Chronic renal failure with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: All are true regarding circumcision except _____.

choices.text: Hemorrhage due to bleeding from frenular artery

questions.solution:
Circumcision is often performed in the neonatal period, infancy, or childhood for cultural or religious reasons and is also performed after the newborn period, when phimosis, paraphimosis, balanoposthitis, or when sexually transmitted diseases are more prevalent. It does not increase the sexual drive.

Medical benefits of circumcision:

  • Reduced urinary infections in infancy
  • Decreased incidence of sexually transmitted disease
  • Marked reduction in the incidence of penile carcinoma

Complications of circumcision:

  • Bleeding is the most frequent complication and occurs in approximately 0.1% of cases.
  • Most infections are minor and superficial, manifested by redness and occasionally purulence at the circumcision site that usually responds to local wound care.
  • A common complication of neonatal circumcision is meatal stenosis, probably produced by a chemical meatitis from ammoniacal urine exposure on the tip of the penis while the patient is still wearing diapers.
  • Serious complications are rare but include recurrent phimosis, wound separation, major tissue loss, concealed penis, skin bridges between the shaft and the glans, inclusion cysts, urethrocutaneous fistula, and loss of some of the glans or, extremely rarely, all of the penis.

Contraindications for circumcision:

  • prematurity
  • anomalies of the penis (like chordee, or curvature of the penis)
  • hypospadias
  • epispadias
  • concealed or buried penis
  • micropenis
  • webbed penis
  • ambiguous genitalia

Bleeding diatheses are not absolute contraindications for circumcision, but it should be avoided in these cases.

questions.text: True statement regarding anion gap is _____
questions.solution:
Phosphates contribute partially to anion gap.

The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real anion gap in the plasma.


However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl− and HCO3−. The anion gap(which is only a diagnostic concept) is the difference between unmeasured anions and unmeasured cations and is estimated as
     

     Plasma anion gap=[Na+]-[HCO3-]-[Cl-]   

                              =148-28-108= 12 mEq

The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall. The most important unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium, and potassium, and the major unmeasured anions are albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and other organic anions.

Usually the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations, and the anion gap ranges between 8 and 16 mEq/L. Here phosphate contributes partially to anion gap.

 

All the other statemtents are false.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: Coadministration of lenalidomide with which other drug increases the risk for thrombosis?
questions.solution: Lenalidomide and thalidomide increase the risk for thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis, stroke, and myocardial infarction, which occur with increased frequency in combination with glucocorticoids and with anthracyclines.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is warfarin induced skin necrosis seen?
questions.solution:
Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is seen in patients with congenital or acquired deficiencies of protein C or protein S.

Warfarin-induced skin necrosis:

  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is seen in patients with congenital or acquired deficiencies of protein C or protein S. Initiation of warfarin therapy in these patients produces a precipitous fall in plasma levels of proteins C or S, thereby eliminating this important anticoagulant pathway before warfarin exerts an antithrombotic effect through lowering of the functional levels of factor X and prothrombin.
  • The resultant procoagulant state triggers thrombosis.
  • A rare complication of warfarin, skin necrosis usually is seen 2–5 days after initiation of therapy.
  • Well-demarcated erythematous lesions form on the thighs, buttocks, breasts, or toes.
  • Typically, the center of the lesion becomes progressively necrotic.
  • Examination of skin biopsies taken from the border of these lesions reveals thrombi in the microvasculature.
  • Treatment involves discontinuation of warfarin and reversal with vitamin K, if needed. An alternative anticoagulant, such as heparin or LMWH, should be given in patients with thrombosis. Protein C concentrate can be given to protein C–deficient patients to accelerate healing of the skin lesions.
  • Occasionally, skin grafting is necessary when there is extensive skin loss.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true regarding Developmental Dysplasia of Hip(DDH)?

choices.text: Thigh and Gluteal folds are asymmetric
Barlow and Ortolani tests are the screening tests performed in suspected newborns
Abduction of hip is increased by 50%

questions.solution:
Abduction of hip is decreased on knee flexion and perineum is widened in DDH.

The Barlow and Ortolani tests are the mainstays in examination of the newborn hip.

Barlow test : This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. The infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. The hip is slowly abducted to 45° and the head is slowly pushed towards the acetabulum by the fingers.

Ortolani test : Here, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. The hip is slowly adducted and abducted to detect any reduction of the femoral head into the acetabulum.

questions.text: A patient has been on total parenteral nutrition via a central venous catheter for 5 weeks. All of the following should be done, except:

choices.text: Monitor for any signs of sudden glucose intolerance
Electrolytes must be checked every 2-3 days
LFT, BUN must be done once weekly
Change central venous catheter tube every two weeks

questions.solution:
A central venous catheter is changed only if the infection is suspected or the catheter is blocked. It need not be changed every 2 weeks.

Total parenteral nutrition (TPN), also referred to as central parenteral nutrition, requires access to a large-diameter vein to deliver the entire nutritional requirements of the individual.

The dextrose content of the solution given is high (15% to 25%). All macronutrients and micronutrients are deliverable by this route.

To monitor or prevent complications, the following steps may be taken:

  • Infections
    • Use subclavian vein preferably
    • Monitor development of glucose intolerance as it is the earliest sign of systemic sepsis
  • Metabolic complications
    • BUN and LFTs weekly
    • Serum electrolytes every 2-3 days
  • Intestinal atrophy
    • Provide at least some nutrients enterally if feasible

 

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: Simvastatin, a lipid lowering drug acts on the rate limiting step of cholesterol synthesis. The reaction product normally produced by this enzyme is
questions.solution:
Mevalonate precedes squalene and lanosterol in cholesterol synthesis.

Methymelonate is not associated with cholesterol synthesis.

choices.text: Lipoprotein lipase or Apo CII deficiency

questions.solution:
Familial type 3 dysbetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive condition caused by defective ApoE.

questions.text: A cyanotic baby at the 8th hour of life is being evaluated in NICU. Pulse oximetry shows 80 % not improving with 100 % O2. Records show that continuous machinery murmur was heard at birth but not anymore. Which of the following can be done?
questions.solution:
This baby has a cyanotic congenital heart disease that is dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus. Prostaglandin E1 infusion prevents the closure of PDA in term neonates with duct-dependent congenital heart disease (CHD).

Cyanosis failing to improve with 100% oxygen suggests an underlying cyanotic CHD.

Functional closure of the PDA occurs soon after birth, usually within first week of life.

The open PDA acted as a conduit between systemic and pulmonary circulations, thereby preventing the onset of cyanosis.

Upon its closure, cyanosis manifested in the baby as the blood could not be pumped into the lungs for oxygenation. Deoxygenated blood is being shunted into the systemic circulation after the closure of PDA. Hence, you should maintain the patency of the duct with PGE1 infusion until surgery can be done.

Duct-dependent lesions: Anomalies, in a newborn with CHD, which are dependent on the patency of ductus arteriosus for survival.

  • Right-sided lesions (Tetralogy of Fallot, PA/PS) cannot pump blood to the lungs. These patients are dependent on an open PDA for pulmonary circulation.
  • Left-sided lesions (Hypoplastic left heart syndrome, Aortic stenosis, Coarctation of aorta) cannot pump blood into the systemic circulation. These patients are dependent on open PDA for systemic circulation.

Indomethacin causes the closure of PDA. This leads to loss of either pulmonary or systemic circulation, eventually causing death. Therefore, indomethacin is contraindicated in duct-dependent CHDs.

questions.text: True about pelvic abscess is _____.

choices.text: Identified by CT if there is full bladder

questions.solution:
Pelvic abscesses may spontaneously drain via rectum.

Pelvic abscess:

The pelvis is the most common site of abscess formation because the vermiform appendix is often pelvic in position and the fallopian tubes are also frequent sites of infection.  A pelvic abscess can also occur as a sequel to any case of diffuse peritonitis, and is common after anastomotic leakage following colorectal surgery.

Clinical features:

The most characteristic symptoms are of pelvic pain, diarrhoea and the passage of mucus in the stools. Rectal examination reveals a bulging of the anterior rectal wall, which, when the abscess is ripe, becomes softly cystic.

Treatment:

  • Identified by CT and USG(USG needs full bladder)
  • Left to nature, a proportion of these abscesses burst into the rectum, after which the patient almost always recovers rapidly.
  • If this does not occur, the abscess should be drained deliberately. In women, vaginal drainage through the posterior fornix is often chosen. In other cases, when the abscess is definitely pointing into the rectum, rectal drainage is employed.
  • It is, however, increasingly common to insert drainage tubes percutaneously, e.g. via the buttock or via the vagina or rectum under CT guidance.

questions.text: Which cancer increases in incidence in AIDS patients?
questions.solution:
The neoplastic diseases considered to be AIDS defining conditions are Kaposi’s sarcoma, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, and invasive cervical carcinoma.

AIDS related malignancy:

  • Kaposi’s sarcoma
  • B cell lymphoma
  • Cervical cancer in women
  • Anal cancer in men

questions.text: A 10 year old malnourished girl with severe anemia and fatigue whose fecal exam detects the egg given in the image. What was the most likely means by which this child was infected?
questions.solution:
This child has the typical symptoms of hookworm disease.

The infection is acquired by penetration of the filariform larvae through the skin of the feet or buttocks, after contamination of soil with the eggs of the agent deposited in human feces.

The eggs are oval and thin-shelled and contain a clearly visible four to eight-cell stage embryo. There is a characteristic clear space between the shell and the developing embryo.

Ascaris egg morphology:

Fertilized and unfertilized Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are passed in stool of the infected host.

  • Fertilized eggs are are rounded and have a thick shell with an external mammillated layer that is often stained brown by bile. 
  • In some cases, the outer layer is absent (known as decorticated eggs).
  • Infertile eggs may be oval or irregularly shaped with a thin shell and containing refractile granules.

Transmission is through the fecal-oral route, usually through the ingestion of eggs.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a suitable home available fluid?
questions.solution:
Weak unsweetened tea is a suitable home available fluid, not sweetened tea. Sweetening raises the osmolality of the solution making it unsuitable.

Suitable Fluids:

  • Plain water
  • Rice water(salted and unsalted)
  • Vegetable/chicken soup
  • Yogurt
  • Tender coconut water
  • Weak unsweetened Tea
  • Unsweetened fresh juices


Unsuitable Fluids:

  • Commercial carbonated beverages
  • Commercial fruit juices
  • Sweetened tea
  • Sweetened fresh juices

questions.text: True about torus fracture in children is

choices.text: Most common site of fracture is distal radius
Plaster cast must be applied for more than 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Torus fracture is an incomplete fracture occurring at the junction of diaphysis and metaphysis, most commonly in the distal radius.

Fracture line is not always visible and tenderness may be the only evidence of fracture. Immobilisation in a splint for 3-4 weeks is enough because 90% of the growth of the forearm occurs distally, there is tremendous remodeling potential for these fractures, especially in young children.

questions.text: True regarding osteosarcoma is:

choices.text: Pathological fracture is the most common presentation
There is increased risk of osteosarcoma in Paget’s disease
Most commonly occurs around the hip

questions.solution:
There is an increased risk of osteosarcoma in Paget’s disease.

Osteosarcoma can be primary or secondary. Secondary osteosarcoma may be related to previous radiation, Paget’s disease, fibrous dysplasia, bone infarcts, chronic osteomyelitis or in dedifferentiated chondrosarcomas.

Patients complain of worsening pain and swelling, particularly suffering night pain, non-mechanical pain or joint restriction. Pathological fracture is rare. Typically metaphyseal or metadiaphyseal, the majority present at the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal femur and humerus.

questions.text: Which among the following types of osteogenesis imperfecta exhibits autosomal recessive inheritance?
questions.solution:
Type VI osteogenesis imperfecta is autosomal recessive. It causes mineralisation defect due to gene SERPINF1.

Types V and VI osteogenesis imperfecta patients clinically have OI similar in skeletal severity to type IV, but they have distinct findings on bone histology. 

Patients with type VI have progressive deforming OI that does not manifest at birth. They have distinctive bone histology with broad osteoid seams and fish-scale lamellation under polarized light.

Inheriance pattern:

  • AD: Type I, II, III, IV, V
  • AR: Type VI, VII, VIII, IX, X, XI , XII

 

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: A physician believes that the nursing staff is uncomfortable talking to him, when in fact, he is uncomfortable talking with them. The defense mechanism used is
questions.solution:
Projection is a defense mechanism that involves taking our own unacceptable qualities or feelings and ascribing them to other people.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Which among the following treatment is done for a women with uterine prolapse who are desirous of future pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Sling surgery or abdominal cervicopexy is designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining child bearing function.

Rectus sheath used as a sling and are anchored to isthmus of the uterus anteriorly with nonabsorbable sutures.

questions.text: Which of the following is a manifestation of cisplatin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Among the options given, ototoxicity is a manifestation of cisplatin toxicity.

Cisplatin is a platinum coordination complex that enters cells by the high-affinity Cu2+ transporter CTR1 and thus degrade the transporter. Inside the cell, the chloride, cyclohexane, or oxalate ligands of the analogues are displaced by water molecules, yielding a positively charged molecule that reacts with nucleophilic sites on DNA and proteins.

Uses:

  • In combination with bleomycin, etoposide, or with ifosfamide and vinblastine, cures 90% of patients with testicular cancer
  • Used with paclitaxel, induces complete response in the majority of patients with carcinoma of the ovary
  • Cisplatin produces responses in cancers of the bladder, head and neck, cervix, and endometrium
  • All forms of carcinoma of the lung; anal and rectal carcinomas; and neoplasms of childhood.
  • The drug also sensitizes cells to radiation therapy and enhances control of locally advanced lung, esophageal, and head and neck tumors when given with irradiation.

Adverse effects:

  • Dose dependent nephrotoxicity
  • Ototoxicity- high frequency hearing loss and tinnitus
  • Peripheral motor and sensory neurotoxicity
  • Anemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • AML, usually 4 or more years after treatment

questions.text: Sistrunk operation is done for ______.
questions.solution:
Sistrunk operation is done for thyroglossal cyst.

A thyroglossal duct cyst is a midline neck lesion that originates at the base of the tongue at the foramen cecum and descends through the central portion of the hyoid bone.

Surgical anatomy:

  • Although thyroglossal duct cysts may occur anywhere from the base of the tongue to the thyroid gland, most are found at or just below the hyoid bone.
  • A thyroid diverticulum develops as a median endodermal thickening at the foramen cecum in the embryonic stage of development.
  • The thyroid diverticulum descends in the neck and remains attached to the base of the tongue by the thyroglossal duct.
  • Also, as the thyroid gland descends to its normal pretracheal position, the ventral cartilages of the second and third branchial arches form the hyoid bone—hence the intimate anatomic relationship of the thyroglossal duct remnant with the central portion.
  • The thyroglossal duct normally regresses by the time the thyroid gland reaches its final position.
  • When the elements of the duct persist despite complete thyroid descent, a thyroglossal duct cyst may develop.

Treatment:

The standard operation for thyroglossal duct cysts has remained unchanged since it was described by Sistrunk in 1928, which involves complete excision of the cyst in continuity with its tract, the central portion of the hyoid bone, and the tract interior to the hyoid bone extending to the base of the tongue.

Failure to remove these tissues entirely will likely result in recurrence because multiple sinuses have been histologically identified in these locations.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true regarding ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: Mostly positive for anti saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies
Microscopically crypt abscesses and ulcers can be seen
Continuous lesions always with rectal involvement

questions.solution:
Only 10 - 15 % of ulcerative colitis patients are positive for anti saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies, whereas 60 - 70 % of crohn’s disease are positive.

Features of ulcerative colitis :

  • Location : Continuous colonic lesions, always with rectal involvement.
  • Gross morphology : Mucosal and submucosal inflammation only. Friable mucosa with superficial and/or deep ulcerations. Loss of haustra “lead pipe” appearance on imaging.

  • Microscopic : Crypt abscesses and ulcers, bleeding, no granulomas. Th2 mediated.

  • Extra intestinal manifestations : primary sclerosing cholangitis. Associated with p-ANCA.
  • Complications :  Fulminant colitis, toxic megacolon, perforation.
  • Treatment :  5-aminosalicylic preparations (eg, mesalamine), 6-mercaptopurine, infliximab, colectomy.

questions.text: Lymphatic drainage of prostate is into
questions.solution:
Lymphatic vessels from the prostate drain mainly in the internal iliac, sacral, and obturator lymph nodes.

Important to note is that lymphatic drainage of the prostate is highly variable. Many of the lymph vessels from the prostate anastomoses with their counterparts of several neighboring organs, for example the urinary bladder and rectum. This can have important clinical implications, especially in cases of prostate cancer.

Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis

questions.text: A 55 year old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer which is found to have extended to the lower end of the vagina. Which stage is it according to the FIGO staging of cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer extended to the lower end of vagina is Stage IIIA according to FIGO staging.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection?

choices.text: Diagnosis is made using urine specimen at 4 weeks of age.
In developing countries, congenital CMV infection is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation.
30-40% of newborns with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth.
CMV is the most common cause of non-syndromic SNHL in children.

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding CMV infection is that congenital CMV infection is the most common cause of non-syndromic sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).

Congenital infection with CMV is mostly asymptomatic, and symptomatic infections can occur in about 10% of newborns (Option C). The vast majority of the cases of congenital CMV throughout the world follow nonprimary maternal infections (Option B).

The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. They can also develop hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions due to dermal erythropoiesis giving the appearance of a blueberry muffin baby. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Laboratory findings include direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevated hepatic transaminases, and thrombocytopenia. A non-contrast CT scan shows periventricular calcifications. Prenatal diagnosis includes the presence of IgM antibodies in the mother or the fetal diagnosis by detecting the virus through the amniotic fluid polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Postnatal diagnosis involves isolation of the virus from the urine or saliva via the DNA PCR or culture within the first 2-3 weeks of life (Option A).

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with oral ganciclovir for 6 months could reduce the extent of hearing loss. Oral valganciclovir can also be used. Regular follow-ups should be done particularly, hearing screening tests. 

Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

questions.text: A female patient complains of palpitations and weight loss. Laboratory evaluation shows thyroid-receptor antibody. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: Associated with enlargement of extraocular muscles

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Graves' disease. Radionuclide scan shows increased uptake with diffuse distribution in Graves' disease.

The hyperthyroidism of Graves’ disease is due to the presence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI). These are synthesized by lymphocytes present in the thyroid gland, as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes. TSI include TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb), which act on the TSH receptors and stimulate the thyroid gland to produce and release more thyroid hormones, T3 and T4. Feedback inhibition by thyroid hormones causes TSH levels to be suppressed (option D).

Patients present with features of hyperthyroidism like hyperactivity, irritability, heat intolerance, sweating, and palpitations. Diarrhea, weight loss despite increased appetite, and oligomenorrhea are also seen. On examination, tremors and proximal muscle weakness might be seen. Pretibial myxedema (option A) refers to the noninflamed indurated plaque, pink-purple in color, which is seen most commonly on the skin of the anterior aspect of the leg. Thyroid acropachy is a form of clubbing of the fingers. Both these features are relatively specific to Graves' disease but are not seen in all the patients.

Graves ophthalmopathy occurs due to increased volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles (option B) due to marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space, accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate, and increased numbers of adipocytes. Early signs of Graves' ophthalmopathy include lid retraction and lid lag on downgaze. Later, the patients develop proptosis, diplopia, corneal damage (due to proptosis), and optic nerve compression causing permanent vision loss. 

The diagnosis of Graves' disease is established by measuring TSH levels (will be suppressed) and T3/T4 levels (will be elevated). Measurement of TRAb is required if the diagnosis is unclear. Radionuclide scan shows diffusely increased uptake in cases of Graves' disease. 

Treatment of Graves' disease includes:

  • Anti-thyroid drugs such as propylthiouracil, carbimazole, and methimazole. Propylthiouracil is the preferred anti-thyroid drug during pregnancy especially till 14-16 weeks, because carbimazole and methimazole are associated with aplasia cutis (absence of skin, usually on the scalp). 
  • Propranolol is given to control adrenergic effects before the effect of anti-thyroid drugs takes effect fully.
  • Radioiodine ablation can be used as a first-line modality, or can be used for patients who have relapsed despite taking anti-thyroid drugs. Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications for radioiodine ablation. 
  • Total thyroidectomy is done for patients who have relapsed despite taking anti-thyroid drugs and prefer surgical treatment over radioiodine ablation.

questions.text: Medium used for intermediate term corneal preservation is
questions.solution:
Medium containing chondroitin sulphate and dextran are used for intermediate-term corneal preservation.

MK medium(McCarey Kaufmann medium) is used for short term corneal preservation.

Related Pearl: Corneal Preservation

Corneal preservation – They can be transplanted immediately or preserved in an eye bank by various preservation techniques for varying intervals.

  • Short-term preservation
    • In a moist chamber or McCarey–Kaufman medium (MK medium)
    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C
    • Cornea to be used within 48 to 72 hours (maximum 96 hours)
  • Intermediate– term preservation
    • In medium containing chondroitin sulfate
    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C for 7 to 14 days
    • Or maintained at 37°C by organ culture methods
    • Using modified Eagle's medium extends this to 30 days
  • Long-term preservation
    • By cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or in glycerol
    • Is up to 1 year
    • Loss of transparency of the tissue is a disadvantage.

questions.text: What is the treatment for bleeding gastric ulcer in a stable patient?
questions.solution:
Distal gastric resection to include the bleeding ulcer is the procedure of choice for bleeding gastric ulcer in a stable patient. Second best procedure of choice is V + D (vagotomy and drainage) with oversewing and biopsy of the ulcer to rule out cancer.

Oversewing of the bleeder followed by long-term acid suppression is a reasonable alternative in high-risk or unstable patients.

Patients with bleeding gastric ulcers present with hematemesis or melena.  Most bleeding stops spontaneously and requires no intervention. However, persistent bleeding is associated with a 6% to 8% mortality.

The most commonly used scores are the Blatchford and Rockall prediction scores.

questions.text: Monoclonal antibodies acting as enzymes are called _____
questions.solution:
Monoclonal antibodies acting as enzymes are called abzyme.

Abzyme:

These are monoclonal antibodies with catalytic activity. Natural abzymes with proteolytic activity are called proteabzymes. And those with DNA hydrolyzing activity are called DNA abzymes.

Granzyme:

Serine proteases that are released by granules within cytotoxic T cells and NK cells. They induce apoptosis in the target cells which may have become cancerous or become infected.

Lipozyme:

It is an hydrolase enzyme that catalyses the reaction between triacylglycerol and water to form diacylglycerol and a fatty acid anion. It is produced in the tongue and pancreas to help in digestion of dietary fats.

questions.text: Elements with the same atomic number, mass number but different nuclear energy are known as _____
questions.solution:
Atoms having the same atomic number and mass number but different nuclear energies are known as isomers. Example: 99m43Tc and 9943Tc.

Isotopes: Forms of a chemical element that have the same number of protons and electrons but differ in the number of neutrons contained in the atomic nucleus. Example: 12C and 14C.

Isobars: Atoms having the same number of nucleons but different numbers of protons and neutrons. Example: 40K, 40Ca, 40Cl.

Isotones: Two atoms are isotones if they have the same neutron number, but different proton number. Example: Boron12 and Carbon13.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image is suggestive of ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy.

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital disorder in which there is a failure of development of the lower abdominal wall through which the bladder is exposed. Chronic exposure of the bladder to the external environment can lead to adenocarcinoma of the bladder. 

Bladder exstrophy can be associated with 

  • Separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis
  • Epispadias
  • In males: Broad and short penis and bilateral inguinal hernia 
  • In females:  Shortened, stenotic, and anteriorly displaced vagina and bifid clitoris 
  • Bladder incontinence
  • Vesicoureteric reflex due to lack of obliquity of the vesicoureteric junction.
  • Imperforate anus, Rectal prolapse

Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. Closure of the abdominal and bladder wall is done in the first year of life. This often requires an iliac osteotomy to relax the tension on the bladder and repair the abdominal wall.

Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects is done.

questions.text: All are true regarding familial adenomatous polyposis except _____.
questions.solution:
Familial adenomatous polyposis is an autosomal dominant disease.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text:
A patient after thyroid surgery develops dyspnoea and stridor without any change in voice. Which of the following nerve is injured?

B/L - Bilateral

U/L - Unilateral

choices.text: U/L superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerves are injured in this case.

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (B/L abductor paralysis), all the intrinsic muscles of larynx (except cricothyroid) are paralyzed. Vocal cords lie in median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. 

Classically, they present with airway compromise leading to dyspnoea and stridor. Voice quality is not affected as the paralysed cords assume their natural adducted position during phonation.

Other options

Option A: In bilateral superior laryngeal nerve paralysis, both the cricothyroid muscles are paralyzed with anaesthesia of upper larynx. Patients present with aspiration of food, cough, and choking fits with a weak and husky voice.

Option C: In unilateral superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis), all the muscles of larynx on one side are paralyzed. Vocal cord on the affected side will lie in cadaveric position. Glottic incompetence occurs as the healthy cord is unable to approximate the paralyzed cord.  They present with hoarseness of voice, aspiration of food, and ineffective cough.

Option D: In unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis, ipsilateral paralysis of all the intrinsic muscles (except cricothyroid) occurs. Vocal cord on the affected side lie in median or paramedian position. Patient maybe asymptomatic. Few may present with voice changes. However, aspiration and airway obstruction does not occur.

Nerve injured Clinical features
Unilateral recurrent layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Asymptomatic
  • Few may have change in voice
  • No airway obstruction/ aspiration
Bilateral recurrent layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Airway obstruction (dyspnea, stridor)
  • No change in voice
Unilateral superior layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Weak voice with inability to raise the pitch
  • Anaesthesia of larynx on one side causing occasional aspiration
Bilateral superior layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Aspiration of food (cough, choking)
  • Weak and husky voice
Unilateral recurrent and superior layngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis)
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Aspiration of food
  • Ineffective cough
Bilateral recurrent and superior layngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis)
  • Aphonia
  • Aspiration of food
  • Inability to cough

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the lateral vestibulospinal tract?
questions.solution:
Lateral vestibulospinal tract is facilitatory to extensor group of muscles.

It is a type of descending medial brainstem pathway. It originates in lateral vestibular nuclei in upper medulla and projects ipsilaterally to neurons at all spinal levels. It activates motor neurons to extensors group of muscles(antigravity muscles) to control posture and balance.

questions.text: An obese female patient had a prolonged second stage of labor. A maneuver that involves sharply flexing the maternal thigh towards the abdomen was done. What condition is this maneuver done for?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and McRobert's manoeuvre is done for this condition.

The manoeuvre allows straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and decreases the angle of pelvic inclination. Even though this does not increase pelvic dimensions, pelvic rotation towards the head usually frees the impacted shoulder.

The below image shows Mc Robert's manoeuvre 

Shoulder dystocia is the impaction of the anterior shoulder behind the pubic symphysis, which fails to deliver with maternal pushing or external traction. It is an emergency since the umbilical cord gets compressed within the birth canal.

Risk factors of shoulder dystocia are fetal macrosomia, maternal obesity, the prolonged second stage of labor, previous history of shoulder dystocia.

Shoulder dystocia is managed according to the following steps:

  1. Call for help, gentle traction with maternal efforts, adequate analgesia
  2. Episiotomy if needed
  3. Suprapubic pressure with simultaneous downward traction of the fetal head
  4. McRobert's maneuver
  5. Woods corkscrew rotational maneuver wherein the posterior shoulder is rotated to 180 degrees.
  6. Rubin maneuver  - here, the fetal shoulder is rocked from side to side by applying pressure onto maternal abdomen. If this is unsuccessful, the doctor inserts hands in pelvis to reach the accessible shoulder and pushes it towards the anterior surface of chest. This leads to a small bisacromial diameter that allows the anterior shoulder to displace from behind the symphysis.

questions.text: What is the range of correlation coefficient?
questions.solution:
The range of correlation coefficient is -1 to +1.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: Touton giant cells are seen in ________
questions.solution:
Touton giant cells or Xanthelasmatic giant cells are seen in xanthomas.

Touton giant cells are modified macrophages which have a central ring of nuclei enclosing a layer of ground‐glass cytoplasm, with a peripheral zone of clearer cytoplasm. They are typically seen in some xanthomas and juvenile xanthogranuloma.

questions.text: A 40 year old man with a rare recessive condition, who had replacement of ectopia lentis, died of stroke.  Addition of which of the following in his diet would have altered his prognosis?
questions.solution:
Supplementation of of vitamin B6 has shown to reduce the level of circulating homocysteine and thus preventing this patient from having a stroke.

Vitamin B6 - Pyridoxine is a cofactor in the synthesis of cystathionine from homocysteine.

Classic homocystinuria is due to cystathionine synthase deficiency which leads to elevated homocysteine levels.

It promotes oxidative damage, inflammation and endothelial dysfunction.

questions.text: A newborn baby at one minute of life has a heart rate 60/min, irregular respiration, with some flexion of limbs. The baby was pale and had a grimace response on passing the nasal catheter. What is the apgar score at one minute?
questions.solution:
This baby has an apgar score of 4. 

Heart rate 60/min- 1

Irregular respiration- 1

Some flexion of limbs- 1

Grimace-1

The baby was pale-0

The Apgar score is a practical method of systematically assessing newborn infants immediately after birth.

An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: The resting muscle length means _____.

choices.text: Length of actin and myosin before contraction
Length at which muscle has minimal tension
Length at which the active tension is maximum

questions.solution:
The length of the muscle at which the active tension is maximal is usually called its resting length.

Other terms related to muscle length and tension:

Passive tension: The tension exerted by unstimulated muscle

Active tension: The tension exerted by a stimulated muscle

Equilibrium length: Length of  relaxed muscle cut free from its bony attachments

questions.text: Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in ______
questions.solution:
Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in prostate carcinoma.

Metastatic tumors of bone:

Metastatic tumors are the most common form of skeletal malignancy, greatly outnumbering primary bone cancers.

Skeletal metastases are typically multifocal. However, carcinomas of the kidney and thyroid may present with solitary lesions. Most metastases involve the axial skeleton (vertebral column, pelvis, ribs, skull, and sternum). The red marrow in these areas, with its rich capillary network and slow blood flow, facilitates implantation and growth of the tumor cells.

The radiographic appearance of metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely blastic (bone forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. Furthermore, some cancers are associated with predominantly one pattern or the other.

For example, prostatic adenocarcinoma is predominantly blastic whereas carcinomas of the kidney, lung, and gastrointestinal tract and malignant melanoma produce lytic lesions.

questions.text: A 2 year old boy is evaluated for a severe combined immunodeficiency disease. Cells populating his thymus is found to lack CD3. Which of the following capabilities would this cell lack?

choices.text: Ability to produce terminal deoxyribonucleotidyl transferase
Ability to proliferate in response to specific antigen

questions.solution:
A cell lacking CD3 would be capable of binding specific antigen, but incapable of activation and proliferation in response to that first signal.

CD3 is the signal transduction complex in T lymphocytes. When specific antigen binding has occurred on the surface of the cell, this complex is responsible for transferring the message to the cytoplasm of the cell. This culminates in intracytoplasmic phosphorylation events, which activate the cell and induce its proliferation (cloning).

questions.text: BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of renal cell carcinoma.

BRCA-2 mutation predisposes to the development of prostate and pancreatic cancer. It is also associated with an increased risk of male breast cancer.

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

questions.text: Read the pedigree chart and identify the pattern of transmission.
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the image is X linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male to male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Females transmit mutated gene to 50% of the males.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with claudication in the right lower limb. Arterial doppler reveals a narrowing of the popliteal artery. The diameter was found to be reduced to one-third. How much will the blood flow reduce by?
questions.solution:
The blood flow through the vessel decreases by 81 times.

The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically in the formula called as Poiseuille's law :

Blood flow (F) inside the vessel depends on: 

  • Pressure difference: directly proportional
  • Viscosity: inversely proportional
  • Radius: directly proportional to the fourth power
  • Length of the vessel: inversely proportional

Here, the diameter is reduced to 1/3rd, implying the radius is also reduced to 1/3rd. Therefore, the flow decreases by (1/3) 4 = 1/81

questions.text: Grisel syndrome is
questions.solution:
Grisel syndrome is nontraumatic atlantoaxial instability associated with pharyngeal infections and is found primarily in children.

Inflammatory mediators cause synovial and vascular congestion, periligamentous inflammation, and oedema, resulting in subluxation and finally, may progress to imbalance of cervical spine with complicated neurological outcomes 

Patients classically present with neck stiffness and torticollis-associated painful neck movements.

This syndrome can be seen after

  • rhinopharyngitis,
  • cervical osteomyelitis,
  • rheumatic conditions, and
  • surgical procedures such as adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, repairment of choanal atresia, and mastoidectomy. 

Treatment includes

  • bed rest,
  • antimicrobial therapy,
  • muscle relaxants,
  • anti-inflammatory agents,
  • external fixation,
  • cervical traction, and
  • soft or hard collar
  • If muscle spasm lasts longer than 24 hours, diazepam can be added

Early treatment can prevent the poor prognosis.

questions.solution:
The serological test of this patient indicates chronic carrier state of hepatitis B.

HbsAg is positive only when the patient has acute infection or a chronic carrier and cannot be seen during window period.

Replicative activity (infectivity) is determined with level of HBeAg or HBV DNA.

Anti HbsAg is positive only during recovery or after vaccination.

Note: In contrast to the high titers of IgM-specific anti- HBc observed in acute disease, low titers of IgM anti-HBc are found in the sera of most chronic HBsAg carriers.

questions.text: You are involved in a study about various types of zoonotic diseases. Which of the following is an example of a metazoonosis?
questions.solution:
Plague is an example of metazoonosis.

Metazoonoses are transmitted by invertebrate vectors. In the invertebrate vectors, the infective agent develops or multiplies, and after an extrinsic period of incubation (prepatent period) transmission to another vertebrate host occurs. Examples include arboviral infections, plague, and schistosomiasis

Zoonoses are diseases and infections which are naturally transmitted from other vertebrates to man. They can be transmitted from either animals or other humans.

Zoonoses are classified based on their reservoir hosts:

  • Anthropo-zoonoses are infections transmitted to man from lower vertebrate animals, e.g. rabies.
  • Zoo-anthroponoses are infections transmitted to lower vertebrate animals from a man, e.g. tuberculosis of cat and monkey
  • Amphixenoses are infections maintained in both men and lower vertebrate animals that may be transmitted in either direction, e.g. staphylococcal infections

Related Pearl: Classification of Zoonoses

Classification based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification based on life cycle if infecting agent is:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact/fomite/mechanical vector

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission.

Rabies , Trichinosis, Brucellosis

Cyclo-zoonoses

More than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle. Invertebrate hosts will not suffice.

 Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Meta-zoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors. Inside the invertebrate, the infective agent develops / multiplies. After an extrinsic period of incubation, the infective agent is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

Arboviral infections, Plague and Schistosomiasis

Sapro-zoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil/ plants)developmental site/reservoir.

Various forms of larva migrants and mycoses
