questions.text: A child with delayed developmental milestones, lethargy and megaloblastic anemia which does not respond to treatment with iron, folic acid ,vitamin B12 or pyridoxine, with elevated level of orotic acid in urine.  Which among the following will alleviate the symptoms?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Uridine is a pyrimidine nucleoside that can be useful in treating orotic aciduria as it bypasses the missing activity in the pathway and can be converted to other pyrimidines.

Orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase. This enzyme contains two activities, orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and orotidine decarboxylase. The lack of pyrimidines impairs nucleic acid synthesis needed for hematopoiesis, explaining the megaloblastic anemia in this infant. Orotic acid accumulates and spills into the urine, resulting in orotic acid crystals and orotic acid urinary obstruction. The presence of orotic acid in urine might suggest that the defect could be ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, but the lack of hyperammonemia rules out a defect in the urea cycle.

Adenine, Guanine and hypoxanthine are purines.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic after prolonged starvation develops severe hypoglycemia. In addition to that which of the following is most commonly expected ?
questions.solution:
Severe hypoglycemia leads to increase in glucagon levels which favors increased fatty acid release from adipose tissue and ketogenesis in the liver.

Ethanol metabolism ↑ NADH/NAD+ ratio in liver, causing:

  • Oxaloacetate → malate (prevents gluconeogenesis → fasting hypoglycemia)
  • ↑ utilization of acetyl-CoA for ketogenesis → ketoacidosis.
  • Dihydroxyacetone phosphate → glycerol-3-phosphate (combines with fatty acids to make triglycerides → hepatosteatosis)
  • Pyruvate → lactate (lactic acidosis)

questions.text: Which among the following is false about rhinoscleroma?

choices.text: It is an infection caused by a gram positive bacillus
Laryngeal infection can also occur as a part of the disease
Mikulicz cells are macrophages filled with the causative organism
It can be treated with fluoroquinolones

questions.solution:
Rhinoscleroma is caused by a gram negative coccobacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis causes this progressive granulomatous infection of the nose and upper respiratory tract, with laryngeal involvement in up to 50 per cent of cases. There are three stages:

  • atrophic, with crusting similar to atrophic rhinitis
  • granulomatous or proliferative, with nodule formation
  • cicatrizing, with stenosis and adhesion formation.

Mikulicz cells - macrophages with phagocytosed bacteria

Russell bodies - plasma cells with eosinophillic inclusion bodies are diagnostic on biopsy.

It can be treated with fluoroquinolones, tetracycline and supportive airway management.

questions.text: Cranial nerve nuclei situated at the level of inferior colliculus is
questions.solution:
The 4th nerve nuclei lies in the ventromedial periaqueductal grey immediately adjacent to the medial longitudinal fasciculus at the level of the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

The 3rd nerve nuclei and the nucleus of Edinger-Westphal are found just beneath the periaqueductal gray near the midline at the level of the superior colliculi in the midbrain.

5th nerve nuclei - motor nucleus is situated medially and sensory nucleus laterally in the pons. The spinal trigeminal nucleus is a caudal continuation of the main sensory nucleus, extending from the mid pons through the medulla to the cervical spinal cord.

Th 6th nerve nucleus is found near the midline in the floor of the fourth ventricle just lateral to the medial longitudinal fasciculus in the pons.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true regarding congenital hypothyroidism?

choices.text: Most commonly due to dyshormonogenesis of thyroid hormone
Most common preventable cause of mental retardation
Prolongation of physiological jaundice can occur

questions.solution:
Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism, not dyshormonogenesis of thyroid hormone.

Other causes of severe fetal hypothyroidism:

  • Maternal hypothyroidism
  • Thyroid agenesis
  • Thyroid dysgenesis 
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Dyshormonogenetic goiter

It is twice as common in girls as in boys and is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Causes of congenital hypothyroidism can be classified based on the presence of goiter as follows:

           Goitrous (Palpable goiter)

     Non-goitrous (No palpable goiter)
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis (30%)
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Placental passage of antithyroid drugs
  • Thyroid dysgenesis (65%)
  • Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies (5%)
  • Central hypothyroidism

 Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia - early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation - usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular - slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory - macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological - macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with hematinics
  • Nervous system - hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness and somnolence, feeding difficulties

The abdomen is large, and an umbilical hernia is usually present. The temperature is subnormal, often <35°C (95°F), and the skin, particularly that of the extremities, may be cold and mottled. Edema of the genitals and extremities may be present. 

6 Ps: Pot-bellied, Pale, Puffy-faced child with Protruding umbilicus, Protuberant tongue, and Poor brain development.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor of endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
Smoking is not a risk factor of endometrial cancer.

Risk factors of endometrial carcinoma includes

  • Prolonged use of estrogen without progestins
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Nulliparity
  • Late menopause
  • Early menarche
  • Lynch syndrome.

questions.text: A  59-year old man presented with persistent wheezing, episodes of hemoptysis, and dry cough. Bronchoscopy revealed a mass occluding the left bronchus. Biopsy of the specimen revealed polygonal cells with fine stippled chromatin and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests. The tumor was positive for CD 56, synaptophysin, and chromogranin. What is the cell of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchial carcinoid. Bronchial neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) arise from Kulchitsky cells.

WHO divides neuroendocrine neoplasms into four categories:

  • Typical carcinoid
  • Atypical carcinoid 
  • Large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma 
  • Small-cell carcinoma 

Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms that represent 1% to 5% of all lung tumors. It is not related to smoking. Carcinoids may occur in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.

On gross examination, these tumors grow as fingerlike or spherical polypoid masses that project into the lumen of the bronchus or as collar button lesions, penetrating the bronchial wall to fan out in the peribronchial tissue.

Histologically, the tumor is composed of organoid, trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. On electron microscopy, the cells exhibit the dense-core neurosecretory granules. 

Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for serotonin, neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, calcitonin, or other peptides.

10% of the cases may produce carcinoid syndrome.

Most carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and have good prognosis.

questions.text: A child is suspected to have renal scarring. Best imaging modality to detect this is _____.
questions.solution:
99mTc-DMSA scan is the best imaging modality to detect renal scarring as it is used to picture the renal morphology and cortical function.

Approximately 60% of administered 99mTc-DMSA is taken up by the proximal tubular cells, mainly through the peritubular arterioles. It accumulates in the cortical tubules within 1 hour and remains for 24 hours.

Homogeneous distribution on high spatial imaging 2-3 hours after DMSA administration confirms normal cortex.

Renal scarring appears photopenic(meaning the area of scarring doesn’t show up as picking up any signal).

DMSA is superior to Intravenous urogram(IVU). Voiding cystourethrogram(VCUG) or Micturating cystourethrogram(MCU) should be done only after scarring is found through DMSA scan.

questions.text: The following is a pre-malignant condition?
questions.solution:
Actinic cheilitis is a premalignant condition.

It is a premalignant keratosis of the lip caused by prolonged exposure to the sun. It is also called sailor’s lip or solar cheilosis.

Actinic cheilitis tends to affect the lower lip of adults. Initially there is redness and edema. Then, the epithelium becomes palpably thickened with small greyish‐white plaques and, eventually, warty nodules may form.

Biopsy may be required to diagnose it.

Treatment:

  • Topical agents: 5% fluorouracil three times daily for 10 days is suitable. Topical tretinoin, trichloracetic acid or diclofenac gel may also be effective.
  • Vermilionectomy (lip shave)
  • Laser ablation
  • Photodynamic therapy sometimes also with imiquimod.

Following treatment, the regular use of a sunscreen lip salve containing p ‐aminobenzoic acid probably gives the best protection.

questions.text: Causative organism of majocchi’s granuloma is _____.
questions.solution:
Majocchi’s granuloma is caused by Trichophyton rubrum.

It is nodular and plaque-like lesions of the lower leg, most common in females and showing a histological picture of a granulomatous perifolliculitis. They are present in the subcutis.

Various fungi have been implicated, including T. rubrum, M. canis, T. violaceum, T. tonsurans, T. mentagrophytes, and Aspergillus fumigatus.

It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals.

Note: This disease is not to be confused with Majocchi’s disease(purpura annularis telangiectodes) which is an idiopathic pigmented purpuric dermatosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Meckel’s diverticulum?

choices.text: It is located 60 cm from the ileocecal valve
It is the most common congenital anomaly of the GI tract
Diverticular inflammation causes referred pain to the inguinal region
It is present in the anti-mesenteric border of terminal ileum

questions.solution:
Diverticular inflammation does not cause referred pain to the inguinal region.

Diverticular inflammation mimics acute appendicitis with referred pain to periumbilical region as both are derived from midgut structures.

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Located approx 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • Approx 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.
  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)

questions.text: Invasion of tissue by tumor cells is assisted by _____.
questions.solution:
Invasion of tissue by tumor cells is assisted by plasminogen activator.

Invasion of extracellular matrix:

  • Loosening up of tumor cell-tumor cell interaction
  • Degradation of Extracellular Matrix(ECM)
  • Attachment to novel ECM components
  • Migration and invasion of tumor cells

The second step in invasion is degradation of extracellular matrix and is carried out by proteases such as matrix metalloproteinases(MMPs), cathepsin D, urokinase plasminogen activator.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding transfusion-related acute lung injury?

choices.text: High titers of HLA antibodies are seen in donor plasma
Nulliparous women are the implicated donors
Patient presents with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.solution:
In cases of transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI), the implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. It may occur in any recipient.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient WBCs. The WBCs aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. TRALI is one of the most common causes of transfusion-related fatalities. The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray, either during or within 6 hours of transfusion. 

Recipient factors that are associated with increased risk of TRALI include

  • smoking
  • chronic alcohol use
  • shock, liver surgery
  • mechanical ventilation with >30 cmH2O pressure support.

Treatment is supportive and patients usually recover without sequelae.

questions.text: Highest percentage of basophilic cell type in anterior pituitary is _____.
questions.solution:
Gonadotropes are the highest percentage of basophilic cell type in anterior pituitary.

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: Parasomnia associated with Stage 2 sleep
questions.solution:
Parasomnias are abnormal behaviors or experiences that arise from or occur during sleep.

Bruxism is commonly seen in stage 2 sleep.

Night terrors and Enuresis is seen in stage 4 sleep.

Nightmares are seen in REM sleep.

Recent update: NREM sleep is divided into three stages: N1, N2, and N3. A fourth stage, N4, was previously recognized only under older scoring standards, but newer standards have incorporated stage N4 into stage N3. NREM sleep typically comprises the majority of the total sleep time in adults.

Sleep cycles and associated events occurring in different stages of sleep are a frequently tested topic in entrance exams. 

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: A 70 year old female presented with memory loss and not able to perform her day to day activities. MRI showed diffuse cortical atrophy and Hippocampal atrophy. Which of the following is true regarding the microscopic findings of the brain?

choices.text: Senile neuritic plaques are extracellular β-amyloid core
Intracellular eosinophilic inclusions composed of α-synuclein can be seen
Extracellular hyperphosphorylated Tau protein can be seen

questions.solution:
Senile plaques in gray matter are extracellular β-amyloid core that may cause amyloid angiopathy.

Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular hyperphosphorylated Tau protein.

Intracellular eosinophilic inclusions composed of α-synuclein are Lewy bodies can be seen in parkinson disease.

Ubiquitinated TDP 43 can be seen in Pick disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old, non diabetic and normotensive man comes with complaints of pain over the heel that is most severe while taking the first step in the morning and aggravated on dorsiflexion. The appropriate diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
The above given complaints are suggestive of plantar fasciitis.

The pain is often worse when first getting up in the morning, with typical hobbling downstairs, or when first getting up from a period of sitting – the typical start-up pain and stiffness.

In Achilles tendonitis pain is increased with activity.

In calcaneal stress fractures there may be a history of unaccustomed and repetitive activity or one of a strenuous physical exercise programme. A common sequence of events is: pain after exercise – pain during exercise – pain without exercise.

In tarsal tunnel syndrome, there is pain and sensory disturbance in the medial part of the forefoot, unrelated to weight bearing, may be due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus. The pain is often worse at night and the patient may seek relief by walking around or stamping the foot.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with a seizure disorder is started on phenytoin therapy. Which of the following must be supplemented in this patient?
questions.solution:
Usage of phenytoin leads to folate deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. Hence, folic acid must be supplemented.

Related Pearl: Difference between B12 and Folic acid Deficiency

Laboratory Tests

Pernicious Anemia (B12 Deficiency)

Folic Acid Deficiency

Serum B12 level

Decreased

Normal

Serum folic acid level

Normal

Decreased

Serum LDH level

Increased

Normal

Achlorhydria

Present

Absent

Schilling Test

Positive

Negative

Methyl malonyl CoA in urine

Present

Absent

Neurological signs

Present

Absent

questions.text: Floor of the femoral triangle is formed by all except
questions.solution:
Floor of the femoral triangle is formed by pectineus, adductor longus and iliopsoas muscles.

Medial border is formed by the medial border of adductor longus.

Lateral border by the sartorius.

Contents : Femorals vessels, femoral nerve, lymph nodes and fat.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: Burst fracture of spine is due to
questions.solution:
If the vertebral body is crushed in neutral position of the neck, the result is a burst fracture. Burst fracture of spine is due to compression type injury.

Flexion distraction injuries are seen in people who wear a lap belt without a shoulder harness. Translational injuries involves malalignment of neural canal, which has been totally disrupted.

questions.text: Study in which cases act as their own controls are known as _____.
questions.solution: The study in which cases act as their own controls are known as case crossover study. Patients are randomly assigned to the study and control group, and then after a period of time, their groups are switched.This also allows for maximum comparability between the experimental and the control group.

questions.text: Holstein Lewis fracture is

choices.text: Lateral condylar fracture of humerus and ulnar nerve palsy
Humerus shaft fracture and radial nerve injury
Humerus surgical neck fracture and axillary nerve injury

questions.solution: Holstein–Lewis fracture - Radial nerve palsy occurring with shaft fractures of humerus, particularly oblique fractures at the junction of the middle and distal thirds of the bone.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with complaints of multiple skin lesions over his back. On examination, various erythematous, scaly lesions parallel to the ribs are noted, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing the Christmas tree sign, is suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

Pityriasis rosea/pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults.

Even though the exact cause is unknown, T-cell-mediated immunity and infectious etiology are thought to be responsible for this condition. An association with infectious agents like human herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) and human herpesvirus-7 (HHV-7) has been found recently.

Clinical features include:

  • Prodrome of a sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbance, fever, or arthralgia.
  • Herald patch - Large and conspicuous eruptions on the thigh, upper arm, trunk, or neck covered by fine scales

The image given below shows a herald patch.

  • After 5-15 days, it turns into discrete oval lesions, dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery-grey scales. 
  • These secondary lesions occur as macules and papules that are elliptical or ovular, symmetric, and commonly involve the thorax, back, and abdomen.
  • It is followed by a marginal collarette of scale with central wrinkling and atrophy. The collarettes of the scales are attached peripherally. It is also called a hanging curtain sign.

The image given below shows collarette scales.

  • The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of skin tension parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.

 The images given below show a Christmas tree pattern along the lines of skin tension on the back and the chest.

The rashes of pityriasis rosea usually resolve in 8 weeks.

Dermatoscopy shows:

  • Yellowish background-color
  • Peripheral arrangement of the scales
  • Patchy distribution of loosely arranged dotted vessels

Histopathology shows:

  • Superficial perivascular dermatitis with focal parakeratosis, hyperplasia and spongiosis in the epidermis.
  • Extravasated red blood cells, along with a perivascular infiltrate and subcorneal pustules, are seen in the dermis.

No treatment is required for asymptomatic cases. Application of irritants to the skin and tanning should be avoided since it may result in pigmentary changes. Emollients and antihistaminics are useful in relieving itching. If symptomatic, various agents are used like:

  • First-line agents: If severe pruritus or poor cosmetic appeal is present
    • Topical steroids
    • Narrowband UV-B therapy
  • Second-line agents: For a rapid resolution of the lesions, given the probable infectious etiology.
    • Antivirals like acyclovir
    • Macrolides like erythromycin

Pityriasis rosea within the first few weeks of gestation may cause premature delivery and fetal demise. Pityriasis rosea-like eruptions were reported after ingestion of drugs like gold, captopril, aspirin, metronidazole and clonidine and after vaccinations like BCG, influenza, diphtheria, hepatitis B, and Pneumococcus.

Other options:

Option A: Lichen planus has violaceous polygonal pruritic papules. It also has Wickham's striae.

Option C: Psoriasis has silvery-white plaques.

Option D: Pityriasis rubra pilaris has circumscribed follicular keratoses.

questions.text:
A 40 year old female complains of chronic cough with recent onset hemoptysis for 1 week.  Lab investigations are positive for anti myeloperoxidase
ANCA with a serum creatinine of 3.3 mg/dl. Urinalysis shows RBC cast and hematuria. The most likely cause for this presentation is?
questions.solution:
The above given findings is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis.

It is a necrotizing vasculitis commonly involving lung, kidneys, and skin with pauci-immune glomerulonephritis and palpable purpura. They are positive for MPO - ANCA/p - ANCA. Presentation is similar to granulomatosis with polyangiitis but without nasopharyngeal involvement.

questions.text: Congenital Lobar emphysema most commonly affects
questions.solution:
Congenital lobar emphysema most commonly affects left upper lobe.

Congenital deficiency of the bronchial cartilage, external compression by aberrant vessels, bronchial stenosis, redundant bronchial mucosal flaps, and kinking of the bronchus caused by herniation into the mediastinum have been described as leading to bronchial obstruction and subsequent congenital lobar emphysema.

questions.text: Which among the following putrefactive changes can be seen in less than 48 hours after death?

choices.text: Loosening of scalp hair, nails and teeth

questions.solution:
Postmortem blister formation can be seen in 18 - 48 hours.

Loosening of scalp hair, nails and teeth can be seen in seen >48 hours.

Postmortem slipping of skin and Changes in external genitalia can be seen in 48 - 72 hours.

questions.text: Patient is treated with dantrolene as a treatment of malignant hyperthermia. All of the following are adverse effects except _____.
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is a known side effect of dantrolene.

Dantrolene is a calcium channel blocker that causes skeletal muscle relaxation by inhibiting calcium release from endoplasmic reticulum through ryanodine receptor.

It is used in the management of malignant hyperthermia, skeletal muscle spasticity due to UMN lesions, neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Side effects include bradycardia, breathlessness, muscle weakness, hepatotoxicity and hyperkalemia.

questions.text: True about single exposure, common vector outbreak is ______.

choices.text: All cases do not occur within one incubation period

questions.solution:
Single exposure, common vector outbreak is explosive.

  • Point source epidemics are also called single exposure epidemics and belong to the common source type of epidemics.
  • The exposure to disease agent is brief and all cases develop within one incubation period.
  • In the epidemic curve, there is a sharp rise and fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period and there are no secondary waves.
  • Infectious agents, environmental pollution and contamination of food are common causes of point epidemics.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A 30 year old man with Crohn’s disease comes with complaints of unilateral eye pain ,photophobia and diminished vision. Slit lamp examination reveals plenty of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber. Which among the following drug is given for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case of uveitis associated with inflammatory bowel disease.

Treatment of uveitis involves mydriatics and cycloplegics - to avoid synechiae formation, steroids and immunomodulators for severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is not pierced during a lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
Posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced during a lumbar puncture.

The structures pierced, from outside in, during a lumbar puncture are:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous fat
  • Supraspinous ligaments
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

questions.text: Most common benign tumor of esophagus is _____
questions.solution:
The most common benign tumor of esophagus is Leiomyoma.

Benign esophageal tumors are uncommon and usually discovered incidentally. In decreasing frequency of occurrence, cell types include leiomyoma, fibrovascular polyps, squamous papilloma, granular cell tumors, lipomas, neurofibromas, and inflammatory fibroid polyps. These generally become symptomatic only when they are associated with dysphagia and merit removal only under the same circumstances.

questions.text:
A 55 year old chronic smoker comes with complaints of persistent cough for the past 4 months with episodes of hemoptysis and he has lost 7 kg. On examination he has normal breath sounds and temporal wasting is evident.His lab values are:
Sodium : 123 meq/L, Potassium : 4.0 mEq/L, Chloride : 96 mEq/L, Bicarbonate : 25 mEq/L, Urea : 12 mg/dL, Creatinine : 0.9 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution: This patient with the above findings likely has lung cancer. Small cell lung cancer is strongly associated with smoking and is the most common cause of SIADH due to ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. Fluid restriction is the best initial treatment for hyponatremia due to SIADH.

questions.text: Schiller Duval bodies are pathognomonic for
questions.solution:
When present, the Schiller-Duval body is pathognomonic for yolk sac tumor.

Schiller-Duval body consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

questions.text: Poikiloderma vasculare atrophicans is most commonly associated with _____.
questions.solution:
Poikiloderma vasculare atrophicans is associated with mycosis fungoides.

The lesions of mycosis fungoides may have an atrophic surface, or present as true poikiloderma with atrophy, mottled dyspigmentation, and telangiectasia. Poikiloderma vasculare atrophicans most commonly represents a clinical form of patch-stage mycosis fungoides.

It is rarely associated with dermatomyositis and SLE.

Mycosis fungoides is cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CD4+ Helper T cells) which usually stays confined to the skin. It can disseminate into the blood which is known as Sezary syndrome. It presents as diffuse erythema of the skin (erythroderma).

Mycoses fungoides present as scaly red-brown patches, raised scaling plaques, and fungating nodules. It passes through 3 phases:

  • Inflammatory pre-mycotic phase - eczema like lesions
  • Plaque phase- raised plaques are seen
  • Tumor phase- multiple tumor nodules indicating systemic spread

Characteristic pathological features of mycosis fungoides:

  • The histological hallmark of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides type) is the presence of Sezary-Lutzner cells, which form band like aggregates within the superficial dermis and invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters called Pautrier microabscess. These cells have markedly infolded nuclear membranes giving it a cerebriform contour
  • Patches and plaques show prominent infiltration by Sezary-Lutzner cells (epidermotropism), in advanced cases, there is inward spread to the dermis and spread symmetrically

It usually involves limb/girdle, breast, and especially the buttock area.

Analysis of TCR genes is now a standard approach that has diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic implications. It consists of the analysis of the TCR gene for clonal rearrangements which is a marker of a monoclonal T‐cell population. T‐cell clones can be detected in a proportion (70% overall) of skin biopsies from patients with early‐stage disease and are almost invariable in patients with later stages of the disease.

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding the enzyme glucokinase?
questions.solution:
Glucokinase has higher Km - low affinity.

Glucokinase is an enzyme situated only in liver and pancreatic beta cells that phosphorylates glucose to yield glucose-6-phosphate, the first committed step of glycolysis. 

It permits hepatic uptake of large amounts of glucose after a carbohydrate meal, for glycogen and fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following organs are spared in Familial Mediterranean Fever?
questions.solution:
The organs spared in Familial Mediterranean Fever are liver and pancreas.

questions.text: Metamorphopsia is seen in all except
questions.solution: Metamorphopsia is distortion of images. It is usually seen in lesions involving macula. It is not a feature seen in vitreous hemorrhage. Symptoms of vitreous hemorrhage includes sudden painless loss of vision or blurry vision, floaters, red haze.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding follicular carcinoma of thyroid?
questions.solution:
Vascular dissemination  to bone, lungs, liver is common in follicular carcinoma of thyroid.

They are single nodules that may be well circumscribed or widely infiltrative.

Most common carcinoma of thyroid is papillary carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: A 26 year old male who has a history of rheumatic fever presents with a rumbling mid diastolic murmur at the apex which follows an opening snap. Which of the following is inversely correlated with the severity of his present condition?

choices.text: Interval between opening snap and S2

questions.solution: The above given finding is suggestive of Mitral stenosis. The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with the severity of the MS.

questions.text: A 55 year old female hypertensive on telmisartan and spironolactone develops hypotension and bradycardia. ECG shows tall T waves. Which among the following ECG findings cannot be seen in this patient as his condition worsens?
questions.solution:
In hyperkalemia there is shortening of QT interval.

Typical ECG findings in hyperkalemia progress from tall, “peaked” T waves and a shortened QT interval to lengthening PR interval and loss of P waves, and then to widening of the QRS complex culminating in a “sine wave” morphology and death if not treated.

questions.text: Mass campaign for screening for measles is carried out when ______ suspected cases are found in a single block in 1 month.
questions.solution: Mass campaign for screening for measles is carried out when more than 5 suspected cases are found in a single block in 1 month.

questions.text: A 36 year old HIV patient undergoes lumbar puncture which revealed organisms visible by India ink. Which among the following is true regarding that organism?

choices.text: It can also be seen as “spaghetti and meatballs” on KOH stain
It consists of branching septate hyphae
It exists as a mycelial form at room temperature and a yeast at 37°C
It is an encapsulated non dimorphic yeast found worldwide

questions.solution:
The causal agent is Cryptococcus neoformans. C. neoformans is the number one cause of meningitis in AIDS patients. It is an encapsulated monomorphic fungi.

“Spaghetti and meatballs” KOH describes Malassezia furfur.

Branching septate hyphae describes Aspergillus.

Mycelial form at room temperature and a yeast at 37°C describes all the dimorphic fungi.

questions.text: Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in  Miller-Fisher syndrome?
questions.solution:
Dystonia is unlikely to be seen in Miller Fisher syndrome.

Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) is a rare variant of Guillain-Barré Syndrome, it accounts for about 5% of cases, and is characterized by a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia (without weakness). It is often associated with pupillary paralysis. 

Patients present with diplopia followed by gait and limb ataxia. Cranial nerves other than ocular motor nerves may be affected. 

The ataxia is attributed to a peripheral mismatch between proprioceptive input from the muscle spindles and the kinesthetic information from joint receptors. Motor strength is characteristically preserved.

Serum IgG antibodies to the ganglioside, GQ1b, are found in more than 90% of patients with MFS.

The prognosis is good with recovery starting within 2-4 weeks of the onset of symptoms. It is treated with IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulins) or plasmapheresis.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: A hypertensive patient with congestive cardiac failure develops sudden onset skin rashes, tongue swelling, and stridor. He had taken a newly prescribed tablet today morning. Which medication is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of drug-induced angioedema. The drug most likely to have caused this is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor like captopril. 

ACE inhibitors can cause angioedema in a small group which presents as swelling of the throat, mouth, tongue, and glottis. It is usually self-limiting once the drug is discontinued. Glucocorticoids, antihistamines, or epinephrine can be given if required. 

Other adverse effects include hypotension, dry cough, hyperkalemia, and skin rashes. In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, it can precipitate acute renal failure.  A rarer complication is visceral angioedema marked by vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It is a known teratogen and needs to be replaced with other drugs during pregnancy/ birth control measures should be advised.

These drugs are inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system and are commonly used in hypertension, left ventricular systolic dysfunction, and acute myocardial infarction. 

Other options:

Option A: Propranolol is a nonselective beta-receptor antagonist. Side effects include bronchospasm, depression, and insomnia. It is not recommended for diabetics as it can mask hypoglycemic symptoms.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic can cause hypotension, hypokalemia, and hyponatremia.

Option D: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist which can cause dry mouth, sedation, and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A Female with a history of postpartum hemorrhage requiring massive transfusion with full recovery 6 months earlier is now diagnosed with Sheehan’s syndrome. Which of the following is not seen in this syndrome?

choices.text: Cold intolerance due to lack of TSH and subsequent hypothyroidism
Secondary amenorrhea due to lack of FSH and subsequent anovulation
Regression of secondary sexual characters due to decreased estrogen synthesis from gonads
Salt depletion and hypovolemic shock due to lack of aldosterone

questions.solution:
Aldosterone secretion is not significantly affected by pituitary apoplexy.

 

Pituitary apoplexy is hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction consequent to traumatic major blood loss. If this major blood loss is during delivery it's called Sheehan's syndrome.

 

Sheehan syndrome:

  • The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk for hemorrhage and infarction.
  • Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure.
  • Most prominent among symptoms are the inability to nurse and postpartum amenorrhea.
  • Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years
  • The sequential order of hormone loss in Sheehan’s syndrome is usually GH > Prolactin → FSH/LH → TSH → ACTH.
  • Cortisol levels are affected leading to hypovolemia, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia. But as aldosterone is unaffected there is no salt wasting.

questions.text: Gastric motility is increased by _____
questions.solution:
Gastric motility is increased by erythromycin.

Erythromycin:

It is a macrolide antibiotic. It is an bacteriostatic agent that inhibit protein synthesis by binding reversibly to 50S ribosomal subunits of sensitive microorganisms.

Erythromycin stimulates GI motility by acting on motilin receptors. Erythromycin is used off label as a prokinetic agent in the intensive care setting and in patients with diabetic gastroparesis.

questions.text: All are true regarding Bartter’s syndrome except:

choices.text: Ion transporter defect is in thin ascending limb

questions.solution:
Bartter’s syndrome is associated with mutation of ion transporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

Bartter’s syndrome is a group of disorders associated with disturbances in electrolyte and acid/base balance, sometimes with nephrocalcinosis and other features. It is due to inactivating mutations of genes encoding Na-K-2Cl transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (TALH). 

Patients with classic BS typically suffer from polyuria and polydipsia, due to the reduction in renal concentrating ability. The combination of hypokalemia and alkalosis in a normotensive, nonedematous patient can be due to Bartter’s or Gitelman’s syndrome. Bartter’s syndrome is distinguished from Gitelman’s syndrome because of hypocalciuria in the latter disorder.

They may have an increase in urinary calcium excretion. Other features include marked activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis. Patients with antenatal BS suffer from a severe systemic disorder characterized by marked electrolyte wasting, polyhydramnios, and hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis; prostaglandin E2 synthesis and excretion are significantly increased, accounting for much of the systemic symptoms.

The form associated with sensorineural deafness has mutation in Barttin gene.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient, a case of frequent recurrence of small cell carcinoma of lung even after multiple episodes of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. The cells are taken and tested in vitro for all chemotherapeutic agents and found to be resistant. Which of the following mutated gene is the tumor most likely to express?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely to express mutation in p53 gene.

Tumors such as lung cancers and colorectal cancers, which frequently carry TP53 mutations, are relatively resistant to chemotherapy and irradiation.

A less obvious but even more nefarious result is that cells with defective p53 acquire a mutator phenotype, a tendency to acquire additional mutations at a high rate. Particularly in patients with advanced stage tumors with mutator phenotypes, it is very likely (and perhaps inevitable) that genetically distinct subclones will arise by chance that are resistant to any single therapy, whether this be radiation, conventional chemotherapy, or molecularly targeted cancer drugs.

questions.text: An HIV patient on antiretroviral therapy presents with seizures and unilateral facial nerve palsy. The CD4 count was 150/microlitre and the MRI showed a lesion as shown below. Which among the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an image of MRI showing ring-enhancing lesions are suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis and the best treatment is the combination of sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin.

In HIV patients, seizures are associated with cerebral toxoplasmosis, primary CNS lymphoma, cryptococcal meningitis, and HIV encephalopathy.

Toxoplasmosis is one of the most common causes of secondary CNS infection in patients with AIDS, but its incidence is decreasing now due to combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). It is generally a late complication of HIV infection and usually occurs in patients with CD4+T cell counts less than 200/microlitre.

Fever, headache, and focal neurologic deficits are the most common clinical presentation of cerebral toxoplasmosis in patients with HIV infection. Patients present with seizure, hemiparesis, or aphasia as a manifestation of these focal deficits or accompanying cerebral edema. It is characterized by confusion, dementia, and lethargy, which can progress to coma.

The diagnosis is suspected on the basis of MRI findings of multiple lesions in multiple locations, although in some cases a single lesion is only seen. These lesions pathologically exhibit inflammation and central necrosis and, as a result, demonstrate ring enhancement on contrast MRI.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin administered for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.

Other options:

Option A- Conventional amphotericin B is given through intrathecal infusion in patients with meningitis caused by Coccidioides.

Option B- Acyclovir reduces mortality and improves the neurological outcome in herpes simplex virus encephalitis.

Option C- Isoniazid (INH), rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol are used in the treatment of tuberculous meningitis.

questions.text: A teenager with severe anorexia nervosa is on nasogastric tube feeding. After 3 days of treatment she presents with altered sensorium. O examination, her heart rate is 98/min, BP 90/60 mmHg. She is febrile and seems well hydrated. Next step in investigation is ______
questions.solution:
This patient has refeeding syndrome. Next step of investigation is serum phosphate levels.

The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia after the cellular uptake of phosphate during the 1st wk of starting to reefed. Serum phosphate levels of ≤0.5 mmol/L can produce weakness, rhabdomyolysis, neutrophil dysfunction, cardiorespiratory failure, arrhythmias, seizures, altered level of consciousness, or sudden death.

Individuals are diagnosed with anorexia nervosa if they restrict their caloric intake to a degree that their body weight deviates significantly from age, gender, health, and developmental norms and if they also exhibit a fear of gaining weight and an associated disturbance in body image.

The condition is further characterized by differentiating those who achieve their weight loss predominantly through restricting intake or by excessive exercise (restricting type) from those who engage in recurrent binge eating and/or subsequent purging, selfinduced vomiting, and usage of enemas, laxatives, or diuretics (binge eating/purging type).

Pure starvation–related malnutrition is a chronic, fairly well adapted form of starvation rather than an acute illness; it should be treated cautiously in an attempt to reverse the downward trend gradually. Although nutritional support is necessary, overly aggressive repletion can result in severe, even life-threatening metabolic imbalances such as hypophosphatemia and cardiorespiratory failure (refeeding syndrome).

Treatment:

When possible, oral or enteral nutritional support is preferred. Treatment started slowly allows readaptation of metabolic and intestinal functions. Weight gain should be undertaken gradually with a goal of 0.5 to 1 pound per week to prevent refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: A 60 year old chronic smoker presents with gradual worsening of shortness of breath. On examination reveals bilateral extensive wheeze. Pulmonary function test shows FEV1/FVC < 0.7. Which among the following is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: There is abnormal permanent bronchial dilatation
FEV1 improves on inhalation of albuterol

questions.solution:
The above given clinical case is suggestive of Chronic bronchitis.

There is always ventilation perfusion mismatch in obstructive lung diseases.

As airways close prematurely at high lung volumes, TLC is increased.

FEV1 shows no change on albuterol inhalation in chronic bronchitis, but it is reversible in asthma.

questions.text: A homeless malnourished chronic alcoholic with right lobar pneumonia undergoes a sputum examination which reveals partially acid fast bacilli with branching rods. Which of the the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Partially acid fast bacilli with branching rods suggest Nocardia. 

Infections caused by Nocardia can occur in immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals.

Nocardia cause three types of skin infections in immunocompetent individuals:

• Mycetoma, a chronic, localized, painless, subcutaneous infection

• Lymphocutaneous infections

• Skin abscesses or cellulitis

In immunocompromised individuals, Nocardia can cause invasive pulmonary infections and disseminated infections.

Patients usually appear systemically ill, with fever, night sweats, weight loss, and a productive cough that may be bloody. Pulmonary infection can lead to complications such as pleural effusions, empyema, mediastinitis, and soft tissue infection.

An acute inflammatory response follows infection, resulting in necrosis and abscess formation. Granulomas are not usually formed.

Mycobacteria are acid fast bacilli but without branching rods.

questions.text: Hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is due to _____

choices.text: Accumulation of lipid peroxides in RBCs

questions.solution:
Hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is due to formation of methemoglobin.

Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase is a housekeeping enzyme critical in the redox metabolism of all aerobic cells. In red cells, its role is even more critical, because it is the only source of NADPH, which directly and via glutathione (GSH) defends these cells against oxidative stress.

The methemoglobin thus formed cannot transport oxygen and unstable. It precipitates in the cytoplasm as Heinz body. It also causes increased cell rigidity and leads to hemolysis.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child has circumferential burns involving both buttocks and both thighs, as well as the face, including the scalp, with singeing of hair. Calculate the approximate percentage of the area involved according to Lund and Browder's chart.
questions.solution:
The approximate percentage of the area involved is 37%.

The age of the child is 1 year and the percentage of burns can be calculated using Lund and Browder’s Chart (which is given below).

  • Head (Face and scalp) → (a-anterior half)8.5 + (a-posterior half)8.5= 17
  • Both thighs circumferentially → (b-left front thigh)3.25 + (b-left back thigh)3.25 + (b-right front thigh)3.25 + (b-right back thigh)3.25 = 13
  • Both buttocks → 2.5 + 2.5 = 5

Total percentage = 17+13+5 = 35%. The closest answer is 37%.

questions.text: Chilaiditi syndrome is

choices.text: Compression of the celiac artery and the celiac ganglia by the median arcuate ligament
Compression of the left renal vein between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta
Partial or complete absence of abdominal muscles and failure of testes descend
Transposition of colon between the diaphragm and liver

questions.solution:
Chilaiditi syndrome is a rare condition in which the colon transposes between the right hemidiaphragm and liver and is one of the causes for pseudopneumoperitoneum.

Chilaiditi sign is the incidental radiographic finding of a rare anomaly with air under right hemidiaphragm without any clinical signs.

Other options :

Compression of the celiac artery and the celiac ganglia by the median arcuate ligament - Median arcuate ligament syndrome(MALS).

Compression of the left renal vein between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta - Nutcracker syndrome

Partial or complete absence of abdominal muscles and failure of testes descend - Prune-Belly syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding common LGBT terminologies and definitions?

choices.text: Bisexual - A person who is emotionally and sexually attracted to people of their own gender and people of other genders
Cisgender - A person whose gender identity and assigned sex at birth correspond
Asexual - A person identifying as having no gender
Gender identity - A person’s internal sense of being a man/male, woman/female, both, neither, or another gender.

questions.solution:
Asexual: A person experiencing little or no sexual attraction to others.

Agender: A person identifying as having no gender.

 While social and cultural acceptance of the LGBT(Lesbian,Gay, Bisexual and Transgender) community has improved in certain parts of the world, many LGBT individuals continue to experience discrimination, stigmatization, and violence. Inequitable healthcare policies and practices, lack of awareness to LGBT health issues, and limited understanding of the unique health needs of LGBT individuals contribute to decreased access to care and disparities in health outcomes for LGBT individuals.

Hospitals and clinics can take a number of steps to create a welcoming and safe space for LGBT patients. This starts by establishing and communicating a nondiscrimination policy that clearly includes gender identity, gender expression, and sexual orientation protections.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is present in brown adipose tissue?
questions.solution:
Thermogenin is present in brown adipose tissue.

The degree of chemical thermogenesis is directly proportional to the brown adipose tissue present. This type of tissue contains a large numbers of special mitochondria where uncoupled oxidation occurs.

Brown fat is supplied by sympathetic nerves that release noradrenaline and stimulate the production of mitochondrial uncoupling protein(also called Thermogenin) and increases thermogenesis.

Other options:

  • Adiponectin & Leptin: Hormones produced by adipose tissue. They reduces insulin resistance.
  • Spectrin: It is found in RBCs. Maintains the shape and flexibility of RBC membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following parotid gland tumor shows hot spot on a 99mTc pertechnetate scan?
questions.solution:
The only neoplasms of salivary glands known to consistently concentrate 99mTc pertechnetate(hot spot) are warthin’s tumor(adenolymphoma) and oncocytoma.

Warthin tumor, or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is the second most common benign parotid tumor and occurs most often in older white men. Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich Warthin tumor and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child weighing 13 kg brought with the complaints of vomiting and diarrhoea with dehydration for 2 days which was corrected with IV fluids. Now, the child looks hydrated but has poor feeding. How much fluid should the child receive?
questions.solution:
This child should recieve fluid at the rate of 46ml/hr.

Hourly Maintenance Water Rate:

  • For body weight 0 - 10 kg : 4 ml/kg/hr
  • For body weight 11 - 20 kg : 40 ml/hr(for first 10 kg) + 2 ml/kg/hr for each Kg beyond 10 Kg
  • For Body weight  >20 kg : 60 ml/hr(for first 20 kg) + 1 ml/kg/hr for each Kg beyond 20 Kg

So, for this child it is 40 ml/hr(for first 10 kg) + (2*3 ml/hr) = 46 ml/hr With total maintenance fluid per day being 1,150 ml.

questions.text: Potential molecule that can be targeted to develop a vaccine, to prevent attachment of the HIV virus to the helper T cells would be ?
questions.solution:
Gp120 is the surface antigen of HIV that mediates its attachment to CD4 lymphocytes.

Gp41 is a transmembrane glycoprotein, and p24, p17, and nucleocapsid protein are all internal molecules, which would rarely be accessible to the immune response.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with chronic suppurative otitis media and cholesteatoma is planned for a mastoidectomy. He is part of the school swimming club and wants to pursue the sport. The patient is allowed to swim after CWD procedure

questions.text: Investigation of choice for pneumoperitoneum is ______.
questions.solution:
Investigation of choice for pneumoperitoneum is CT abdomen.

Erect abdominal X ray is the first test to be ordered for suspected pneumoperitoneum.

Where the plain radiographs are equivocal, then CT is the most sensitive imaging technique for diagnosis of free intraperitoneal air. A small amount of free intraabdominal air can be seen anterior to the liver or midline abdomen (as the mobile air collects anteriorly with the patient in the supine position) and in the peritoneal recesses or retroperitoneal spaces.

This is best appreciated by reviewing the images on lung window settings. CT may identify the cause of pneumoperitoneum and can offer additional information to plain radiographs.

questions.text: Best method to visualise the proximal bile duct is _____.
questions.solution:
Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram (PTC) is the best method to visualize the proximal bile duct.

This is an invasive technique in which a bile duct is cannulated percutaneously using the Chiba or Okuda needle. This is done under radiological control (ultrasound or CT). Successful entry is confirmed by contrast injection or aspiration of bile. Multiple images can be taken, demonstrating areas of strictures or obstruction.

In general, if a malignant stricture at the level of the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts or higher is suspected in a jaundiced patient, a PTC is preferred to ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography).

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about dorsal interossei?

choices.text: First interosseous is the largest of all
The second and third interossei are inserted in the radial aspect of middle and ring finger
Cause abduction of index, middle and ring finger
Innervated by deep branch of ulnar nerve

questions.solution:
The second and the third interossei are inserted into the radial and the ulnar aspect of the middle finger respectively.

The first dorsal interroseus is the largest muscle is sometimes called abductor indicis.

Dorsal interossei abduct the fingers away from the longitudinal axis of the middle finger.

questions.text: During a hearing assessment of a patient, he is able to tell the direction from which the sound is heard. Which of the following is responsible for the detection of the direction of sound?
questions.solution:
The lateral superior olivary nucleus is responsible for the detection of the direction of the sound. It is the starting point for the localisation of sound.

The mechanism by which it detects the direction of the sound is by comparison of the difference in intensities of the sound reaching the two ears and sending the signals to the auditory cortex that can detect the direction.

Other options:

Option B: Lateral geniculate body is seen in the visual pathway. It has two principal functions:

  • It relays visual information from the optic tract to the visual cortex by way of optic radiation
  • To gate the transmission of signals to the visual cortex. It controls how much of the signal is allowed to pass to the cortex.

Option C: The nerve fibres stimulated by the hair cells lead to the spiral ganglion of Corti, which lies in the centre of the cochlea. The spiral ganglion neuronal cells send axons into the cochlear nerve. 

Option D: Nerve fibres from the spiral ganglion of Corti enter the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei located in the upper part of the medulla. At this point, all the fibres synapse, and second-order neurons pass mainly to the opposite side of the brain stem to terminate in the superior olivary nucleus.

Related Pearl: Central Auditory Pathway

Most of the primary auditory cortex is in the temporal lobe, but the association cortices extend over much of the insular lobe and even onto the lateral portion of the parietal lobe.

questions.text: Restriction fragment length polymorphisms may be produced by mutations in the sites for restriction endonucleases. For instance, a single base change in the site for the BamH I(restriction endonuclease) produces the sequence GGATGC, which can no longer be recognized by the enzyme. What is the original sequence that BamH I recognises?
questions.solution:
BamH I is a restriction endonuclease that recognises the sequence GGATCC. BamH I would therefore be unable to recognise the single base change GGATGC.

Restriction endonuclease enzymes recognize and cleave a specific double stranded DNA sequence, most of which are palindromes.

They are used to make restriction maps of DNA, produce fragments for genetic analysis and for making recombinant DNA and cloning DNA sequences.

NOTE : It is interesting to note that BamH I is a restriction endonuclease derived from Bacillus amyloliquefaciens. NARP( neuropathy, Ataxia, Retinitis Pigmentosa) and MILS(Maternally Inherited Leigh Syndrome) syndromes, for example, are mitochondrial diseases that can be caused by mutations in the mitochondrial DNA. Mitochondria can recover its functions after the excision of the mutant sequence through restriction endonuclease.

questions.text: Antibiotics are indicated in which type of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Antibiotics are indicated in guttate type of psoriasis.

Guttate psoriasis is a sudden onset shower of diffuse, small lesions over the body. The lesions are 2-3mm to 1cm in diameter and are slightly round or oral.

The lesions are scattered all over the body but the lesions over the face are sparse and disappear quickly.

Though lesions resolve over 3 months, serological evidence of streptococcal infection can be found in 60% of individuals. Therefore, antibiotic treatment is warranted.

questions.text: Which among the following is the fastest acting antithyroid drug?
questions.solution:
Potassium iodide is the fastest acting antithyroid drug.

Iodides:

Iodides have several actions on the thyroid. They inhibit organification and hormone release and decrease the size and vascularity of the hyperplastic gland. In susceptible individuals, iodides can induce hyperthyroidism (Jod-Basedow phenomenon) or precipitate hypothyroidism.

Improvement in thyrotoxic symptoms occurs rapidly, within 2–7 days, hence used as iodide therapy in thyroid storm.

Note: Other agents take 5 days to several weeks to act.

questions.text: The recent drug approved for the treatment of dry mouth associated with Sjogren’s syndrome is _____
questions.solution:
Cevimeline, a quinuclidine derivative of acetylcholine, is a newer direct-acting muscarinic agonist used for the treatment of dry mouth associated with Sjogren’s syndrome or caused by radiation damage of the salivary glands.

It is a synthetic M3 selective cholinomimetic drug.

questions.text: Patients taking which of the following drugs should be advised to avoid drinking grapefruit juice?
questions.solution:
Patients taking Atorvastatin should be advised to avoid drinking grapefruit juice.

It is because, grapefruit juice inhibits CYP3A4 in the liver, particularly at high doses, leading to decreased drug elimination via hepatic metabolism and can increase potential drug toxicities. Atorvastatin is metabolised via this pathway.

Other options:

  • Aspirin is cleared via renal mechanisms.
  • Pravastatin is not metabolized to any appreciable extent by the CYP system and is excreted unchanged in the urine. However, other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors like lovastatin, simvastatin are metabolised via CYP3A4.
  • Losartan is metabolised by CYP2C9.

questions.text: A 3 month old baby presents with failure to thrive with delayed milestones. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly with elevated transaminases and mild hypotonia. Ophthalmological examination shows cherry red spot on macula. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Niemann Pick disease.

It is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder due to deficiency of sphingomyelinase leading to accumulation of sphingomyelin.

Features : Progressive neurodegeneration, hepatosplenomegaly, foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages) ,“cherry-red” spot on macula.

Other options :

Tay Sach disease is due to deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. It presents similarly with developmental delay and cherry red spot on macula but does not have hepatosplenomegaly.

Gaucher disease : It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder. Presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia,osteoporosis, avascular necrosis of femur, bone crises. Gaucher cells are lipid-laden macrophages resembling crumpled tissue paper.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy: It is due to deficiency of Arylsulfatase A causing central and peripheral demyelination with ataxia, dementia.

questions.text: Risk factors for osteoporosis include all except
questions.solution:
Obesity is not a risk factor for osteoporosis. Low body weight ( BMI < 18.5 kg/m2 )  and low bone mass density are risk factors for osteoporosis.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: Patient presents with the history of recurrent falls. Examination revealed vertical gaze palsy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Steele Richardson syndrome. 


Progressive supranuclear palsy syndrome (PSP-S; also known as Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome) is a degenerative disorder that involves the brainstem, basal ganglia, limbic structures etc.


Clinically, PSP-S begins with falls and executive or subtle personality changes (such as mental rigidity, impulsivity, or apathy). Shortly thereafter, a progressive oculomotor syndrome follow that begins with square wave jerks, followed by slowed saccades (vertical worse than horizontal) before resulting in progressive supranuclear ophthalmoparesis.


Dysarthria, dysphagia, and symmetric axial rigidity can be prominent features that emerge at any point in the illness.


A stiff, unstable posture with hyperextension of the neck and a slow, jerky, toppling gait are characteristic. Frequent unexplained and sometimes spectacular falls are common secondary to a combination of axial rigidity, inability to look down, and poor judgment.

questions.text: Placenta invading the myometrium is
questions.solution:
With placenta increta, villi actually invade the myometrium.

Placenta percreta is defined as villi that penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

Placenta accreta indicates that villi are attached to the myometrium.

The abnormal placental adherence to the myometrium stems in part from partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid layer. If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, then the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.

Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle ibers rather than to decidual cells. This decidual deficiency then prevents normal placental separation after delivery.

The surface area of the implantation site involved and the depth of trophoblastic tissue ingrowth are variable between women, but all affected placentas can potentially cause signiicant hemorrhage.

questions.text: An elderly gentleman presents with weight loss, the passage of dark-colored urine, and pale putty stools. On examination, you note a yellowish discoloration of the skin. Which of the following is likely to be elevated in the serum?
questions.solution:
This case scenario is suggestive of obstructive jaundice in which conjugated bilirubin levels in the serum will be elevated.

Yellowish discolouration of the skin (jaundice), weight loss, dark-coloured urine (bilirubinuria), and pale stools are all indicative of obstructive jaundice.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to the increase in serum conjugated or direct bilirubin levels. It usually occurs due to impaired excretion of bilirubin due to obstructive biliary pathology or hereditary syndromes. The diagnosis can be made by elevation of serum direct bilirubin levels, hepatic enzymes (Alkaline phosphatase specifically raised in cholestasis) and absent urinary urobilinogen. Obstruction of biliary ducts may be intrahepatic or extrahepatic and can be localised by imaging techniques.  

Bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme metabolism which is formed in the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. It is insoluble in water and is known as unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. It is transported to the liver after binding to albumin, where it undergoes conjugation with glucuronic acid. The final product is known as conjugated bilirubin (direct bilirubin) which drains into the duodenum. On reaching the colon, the unconjugated form is acted upon by bacterial beta glucuronidases and reduced into colorless urobilinogen. Almost 90% is excreted through faeces as stercobilinogen, and the remaining will undergo enterohepatic cycling. A small fraction of this escapes hepatic uptake and will be excreted in the urine as urobilinogen.

Normally, urine bilirubin is absent. However, in obstructive jaundice, bilirubin cannot drain to the intestine to be converted into urobilinogen. Thus, fecal urobilinogen becomes absent, which gives the characteristic steatorrhea. The presence of urine bilirubin is an indication of post-hepatic obstruction and presents as cola/dark-colored urine. Increase bilirubin deposition in the skin, resulting in yellowish discoloration and may lead to pruritus.

Serum bilirubin can be measured using the van den Bergh reaction. The bilirubin is exposed to diazotized sulfanilic acid with/without alcohol and total and direct bilirubin levels are measured respectively. Indirect bilirubin levels would be the difference between the two values. 

Related Pearl: Types of Jaundice

Type of jaundice Serum bilirubin Urine Urobilinogen Urine bilirubin
Pre-hepatic ↑ Indirect          ↑        -
Hepatic ↑ Direct and indirect   Normal/ ↓       +/-
Post-hepatic ↑ Direct          -        +
