questions.text: VMAT 2 inhibitor approved for treatment of Huntington's chorea is _____
questions.solution:
VMAT 2(Vesicular monoamine transporter 2) inhibitor approved for treatment of Huntington's chorea is deutetrabenazine.

Other options-

B. Valbenazine: VMAT 2 inhibitor approved for treatment of tardive dyskinesia.(also Deutetrabenazine)

C. Deflazacort: Corticosteroid approved for treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy

D. Edaravone: It is a free radical scavenger approved for treatment of ALS.

questions.text: A young boy presented with a cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that gives the appearance of a frog’s belly. A ranula usually resolves spontaneously.  

A plunging ranula is a mucus retention cyst. It has mucus collecting below the gland and perforating through the mylohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.  

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

Related Pearl: Plunging ranula

It is a form of mucous retention cyst that can arise from both sublingual and submandibular salivary glands and presents as dumb-bell-shaped swelling that is soft, fluctuant and painless in the submandibular or submental region of the neck.

  • It shows cross fluctuation along the mylohyoid
  • Treatment is by removal of the sublingual gland and aspiration of the saliva out from the sac. The cervical approach which was previously used is now contraindicated.
  • Conditions with cross fluctuation are :
    • Plunging ranula
    • Bilocular hydrocele
    • Compound palmar ganglion
    • Psoas abscess

Note:

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.

questions.text: Most common site for ectopic pregnancy is
questions.solution:
Nearly 95% of ectopic pregnancies are implanted in various segments of fallopian tube.

The ampulla is the most frequent site for ectopic pregnancy in the fallopian tube followed by isthmus, fimbria and interstitium.

The remaining 5 percent of nontubal ectopic pregnancies implant in the ovary, peritoneal cavity, cervix, or prior cesarean scar.

questions.text: Wrinkles on the forehead of an old lady are due to decrease in ______
questions.solution:
Wrinkling is due to elastotic degeneration.

Wrinkles are a characteristic of ageing skin. They may be defined as creases or furrows in the skin surface.

There are three morphological types of wrinkles:

  • Crinkles
  • Glyphic wrinkles
  • Linear furrows

questions.text:
A 2 year old boy is admitted for multiple skin infections involving Staphylococcus, pseudomonas and candida. The nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test and neutrophil
oxidative index are negative. What is the most likely defect in this child?
questions.solution:
This patient has NADPH deficiency.

He has had recurrent infections with catalase positive organisms and has a defect in generating oxygen radicals intracellularly in his phagocytic cells (the negative nitroblue tetrazolium test and neutrophil oxidative index). This genetic defect arises from a failure  to produce one of the subunits of NADPH oxidase, which makes the individual incapable of producing intracellular oxygen radicals.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Pneumotaxic centre is located in _____
questions.solution:
It is located dorsally in the superior portion of the pons, which mainly controls rate and depth of breathing.

The function of the pneumotaxic center is primarily to limit inspiration, which in turn increases the rate of breathing. This is because limiting of inspiration also shortens expiration and the entire period of each respiration.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component

Primary function

Pre-Bőtzinger complex

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Overdrive mechanism

Pneumotaxic centre

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Apneustic centre

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Vagi

Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text: Which enzyme is involved in cataract formation in a patient with diabetes?
questions.solution:
Glucose is reduced to sorbitol by aldose reductase.

Sorbitol does not diffuse through cell membranes, but accumulates, causing osmotic damage. This leads to cataract formation in diabetic patients.

Galactokinase and Galactose 1-P uridyl transferase are involved in galactose metabolism.

Aldolase B is an enzyme involved in fructose metabolism.

questions.text:
A 35 year old schizophrenic on a course of neuroleptic medication which has been effective in controlling his hallucinations and delusions, develops dry mouth, constipation and blurry vision.
These symptoms are most likely produced by blockage of what receptors?
questions.solution:
The patient displays the symptoms of anticholinergic intoxication as the result of blockage of the muscarinic receptors.

These anticholinergic side effects are common with low potency neuroleptic drugs like Chlorpromazine, Thioridazine.

questions.text: Identify the given breathing system.
questions.solution:
The given breathing system is the Bain circuit. It is also a type of Mapleson D circuit.

It is a coaxial type of circuit. The identifying feature is the narrow inner tube for the flow of fresh gas. That is, inner tubing is inspiratory and outer tubing is expiratory.

Bain circuit is used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

 

Note: Lack's circuit is a coaxial modification of Mapleson A. Here, inner tubing is expiratory and outer tubing is inspiratory.

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: Which of the USG findings has the highest sensitivity for diagnosis of Intrauterine growth retardation?
questions.solution:
Increase in abdominal circumference < 1cm/week after 34 weeks is suggestive of IUGR.

It is the most sensitive and has the greatest negative predictive value.

Fetal ponderal index =  Weight x 100/Crown-heel length3 

It is used to identify infants whose soft tissue mass is below normal for the stage of skeletal development. When below the 10th percentile it may be used to identify IUGR. It can be calculated by ultrasound examination. It has sensitivity and specificity of 76.9% and 82% respectively.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with recurrent attacks of tonsillitis and speech difficulties was posted for a tonsillectomy procedure. Which of the following position is used in this surgery?
questions.solution:
Rose position is used in tonsillectomy surgery. 

In Rose's position, the patient is supine, with their head extended. A rubber ring is placed under the head to stabilize it and a pillow is placed under the shoulders to extend the head. Rose's position is also used in adenoidectomy and tracheostomy.

 

Indications of tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication
  • Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech
  • Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)
  • As a part of the surgical management of sleep apnea syndrome, glossopharyngeal neuralgia, and Eagle's syndrome.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of the epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

Other options:

Option A: The sniffing position involves flexion of the neck on the body and extension of the head on the neck which is done during tracheal intubation.

Option B: Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions, and for patients with a nasogastric tube. 

Option C: Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.

The below image shows the various surgical positions and the procedure they are used in:

questions.text: Right testicular vein drains into
questions.solution:
Right testicular vein drains into the inferior vena cava while left testicular vein drains into the renal vein.

Because the left testicular vein enters the left renal vein at a 90° angle, flow is less laminar on left than on right.

left venous pressure > right venous pressure → varicocele more common on the left.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of recurrent headaches comes to the OPD with an acute episode of headache lasting for less than 30 minutes with redness and watering in one eye. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of an acute episode in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from cluster headaches. Verapamil is not used for the treatment of acute episodes, but as the first-line preventive treatment for cluster headaches.

Cluster headache is a periodic headache characterized by daily attacks of short-duration unilateral headache lasting 8-10 weeks a year. It presents as severe, unilateral retro-orbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. The pain, though severe, is characteristically brief (15-180 minutes). Patients are usually perfectly well in between episodes.

The most suitable treatment is pharmacologic prevention of future bouts of headaches. An acute episode can be treated with 

  • Sumatriptan 6 mg subcutaneous injection
  • 100% O2 at 10 -12 L/min for 15 - 20 mins
  • Sumatriptan (20 mg) and zolmitriptan (5 mg) nasal spray.
  • Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is also approved by the FDA for the treatment of acute episodes of cluster headaches.

The drugs used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches are:

  • Verapamil - drug of choice
  • Prednisone
  • Lithium
  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Melatonin
  • Greater occipital nerve injection with lidocaine and glucocorticoids

questions.text: A 40 year old man develops pain in the eye following dark room test. Which among the following should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution: Darkroom prone test is done to trigger angle closure in primary angle closure glaucoma suspects. Mydriatics like anticholinergic drugs are avoided in these patients as they can trigger angle closure and precipitate acute acute Glaucoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding SIADH?

choices.text: Urine osmolality is more than serum osmolality
Euvolemia with normal or low urine sodium
Vaptans can be used for treatment

questions.solution:
SIADH is associated with increased urine sodium to >20 mEq/L.

questions.text: Omphalocele is associated with all except
questions.solution:
Omphalocele is not associated with duodenal atresia

It is associated with other anomalies and syndromes such as Beckwith-Wiedemann, conjoined twins, trisomy 18, meningomyelocele, and imperforate anus.

An omphalocele is a herniation or protrusion of the abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical cord. The sac is covered with peritoneum without overlying skin and care should be taken to prevent its rupture.

Gastroschisis is the more common defect and typically the intestines are not covered by a membrane. The exposed intestines should be gently placed in a sterile clear plastic bag after delivery. The infant should be transferred to a tertiary referral center for surgical consultation and evaluation for other associated anomalies.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to ankylosing spondylitis?

choices.text: Less than half of the patients will be HLA B27 positive

questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with plantar fasciitis.

 

Ankylosing spondylitis(AS) is an inflammatory disorder of unknown cause that primarily affects the axial skeleton. Peripheral joints and extra-articular structures are also frequently involved.

It is more common in men. 

AS shows a striking correlation with the histocompatibility antigen HLA-B27. 

In North American whites, the prevalence of B27 is 7%, whereas it is 90% in patients with AS, independent of disease severity.

 

Extra-articular manifestations:

  • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis, which occurs in up to 40% of patients and can antedate spondylitis. Attacks are typically unilateral causing pain, photophobia and increased lacrimation. These tend to recur and is often in the opposite eye.

  • Cataracts and secondary glaucoma are also seen.

  • Up to 60% of patients with AS have inflammation in the colon or ileum. This is usually asymptomatic, but frank IBD occurs in 5–10% of patients with AS.

  • About 10% of patients meeting the criteria for AS have psoriasis.

  • Aortic insufficiency, sometimes leading to congestive heart failure, occurs in a small percentage of patients, occasionally early. Third-degree heart block may occur alone or together with aortic insufficiency. Subclinical pulmonary lesions and cardiac dysfunction may be relatively common. The myocardium is spared.

  • Cauda equina syndrome and upper pulmonary lobe fibrosis are rare late complications.

  • Retroperitoneal fibrosis is a rare associated condition.

questions.text: Which factor is not freely circulating in blood?
questions.solution:
Factor III, also known as tissue thromboplastin, is the only coagulation factor not found in plasma.

It is composed of membrane phospholipids of tissues and a lipoprotien complex that functions mainly as a proteolytic enzyme. Factor III initiates the cascade of extrinsic pathway of clotting.

questions.text: Angiotensin receptor blocker which blocks thromboxane A2 is______
questions.solution:
Angiotensin receptor blocker which blocks thromboxane A2 is losartan.

Losartan is a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor and attenuates platelet aggregation. EXP 3179, a metabolite of losartan without angiotensin receptor effects, reduces COX-2 messenger RNA upregulation and COX-dependent prostaglandin generation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting bacterial RNA polymerase?
questions.solution:
Rifampin acts by inhibiting bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase.

Rifampin enters M. tuberculosis bacilli in a concentration-dependent manner, achieving steady-state concentrations within 15 minutes. Rifampin binds to the β subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (rpoB) to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. Drug binding suppresses chain formation in RNA synthesis.

Other options:

  • Aminoglycosides: The primary intracellular site of action of the aminoglycosides is the 30S ribosomal subunit. Aminoglycosides interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis, leading to the accumulation of abnormal initiation complexes; the drugs also can cause misreading of the mRNA template and incorporation of incorrect amino acids into the growing polypeptide chains.
  • Macrolides: Macrolide and ketolide antibiotics are bacteriostatic agents that inhibit protein synthesis by binding reversibly to 50S ribosomal subunits of sensitive microorganisms.
  • Cephalosporins: Bactericidal agents which act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: Vein of Sylvias is
questions.solution:
Vein of Sylvias is superficial middle cerebral vein.

It runs along the lateral sulcus posteroanteriorly draining the opercular regions of the brain and ends in the sphenoparietal or cavernous sinus.

It is connected to the superior sagittal sinus by the superior anastomotic vein(vein of Trolard).

questions.text: Loffler syndrome can occur due to all except?
questions.solution:
Loffler syndrome does not occur due to enterobius vermicularis.

Loffler syndrome refers to transient pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia that occurs in response to passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs, most commonly larvae of Ascaris species (roundworm). It can also occur due to Hookworms and Schistosomiasis.

questions.text: X-ray finding more suggestive of ulcerative colitis than Crohn’s disease is _____.

choices.text: Tracking of contrast within bowel wall

questions.solution:
X-ray finding more suggestive of ulcerative colitis than Crohn’s disease is loss of haustrations.

All other findings are more commonly found in Crohn’s disease.

questions.solution:
Tensor tympani does not pass through sinus of Morgagni.

Sinus of Morgagni is the interval between the superior constrictor of the pharynx and the base of skull.

Structures passing through sinus of Morgagni includes

  • Auditory tube 
  • Levator veli palatini
  • Ascending palatine artery
  • palatine branch of ascending pharyngeal artery

questions.text: Dupilumab is _____

choices.text: Anti IL 17 A receptor antibody approved for treatment of plaque psoriasis
Anti IL 23 monoclonal antibody approved for treatment of plaque psoriasis
Anti IL 4 receptor alpha antibody approved for treatment of atopic dermatitis
Anti IL 6 monoclonal antibody approved for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis

questions.solution:
Dupilumab is an anti IL 4 receptor alpha antibody approved for treatment of atopic dermatitis.

Other options:

A. Brodalumab: Anti IL 17 A receptor antibody approved for treatment of plaque psoriasis.

B. Guselkumab: Anti IL 23 monoclonal antibody approved for treatment of plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: A 20 year old presents female presents with dyspnea, palpitation and fatigue. Previous history of infective endocarditis is present. On examination, apex beat is hyperdynamic and displaced laterally. Other findings noted were soft S1, low pitched S3 and a pansystolic murmur radiating to axilla. ECHO shows isolated valvular regurgitation. Turbulence arising from this valve can be best heard by placing the stethoscope over:

choices.text: 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line on the left side
5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line on the left side
Right lower end of the body of sternum
Medial end of 2nd intercostal space on the left side

questions.solution:
The auscultation should be done in mitral valve area which is 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line on the left side.

 

The above clinical scenario shows maximum intensity of pansystolic murmur over apex, radiation to axilla. That with history of infective endocarditis and ECHO finding of a single valvular lesion, points to mitral valve pathology. i.e., mitral regurgitation. Hence, auscultation must be done in mitral area.

 

Sites to auscultate using a stethoscope are:

  • Pulmonary area: The sternal end of the left 2nd intercostal space
  • Aortic area: The sternal end of the right 2nd intercostal space
  • Mitral area: 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line on the left side
  • Tricuspid auscultation is done 5th intercostal space over the left lower sternal border.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with grand mal seizures. CT reveals a brain tumor. On the surgical table, it was noted that the tumor had spread in a sheet-like fashion along the dural surface. The gross pathology report mentions an encapsulated tumor with a polypoid appearance. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the gross pathology findings indicate the presence of a meningioma.

Meningioma:

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.

Meningiomas are usually rounded masses with well-defined dural bases that compress the underlying brain but are easily separated from it. The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated by thin, fibrous tissue and may have a bosselated or polypoid appearance.

They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura.

WHO grading of meningiomas:

  • Grade I - Most meningiomas fall under this category. For example - Syncytial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcytic.
    • Simple surgical excision is the treatment.
  • Grade II - They are also called atypical meningiomas. These have a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive growth. For example- Clear cell and chordoid type of meningiomas.
    • These may require radiotherapy in addition to surgery.
  • Grade III - These are called anaplastic (malignant) meningiomas and are highly aggressive tumors - Papillary and rhabdoid meningiomas are examples. Surgical excision of the tumor and the tissue it has invaded is the mainstay.
    • Radiotherapy is an additional treatment. The recurrence rate is high even after tumor excision.

questions.text: TRAP positivity is seen in _____.
questions.solution:
TRAP positivity is seen in hairy cell leukemia.

Hairy cell leukemia is a rare B cell neoplasm(2% of all leukemias). It is a disease of middle aged white males(median age 55) and with a male to female ratio of 5:1.

Hairy cell leukemia follows an indolent course. Clinical manifestations result largely from infiltration of the bone marrow, liver, and spleen. That is, massive splenomegaly(most common abnormal physical finding), hepatomegaly(less common and not as marked), lymphadenopathy is rare. Pancytopenia resulting from marrow involvement and splenic sequestration is seen in more than half the cases. The overall prognosis is excellent.

Diagnosis:

  • Fine hairlike projections that are best recognized under the phase-contrast microscope
  • On routine peripheral blood smears, hairy cells have round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and moderate amounts of pale blue cytoplasm with threadlike or bleblike extensions
  • Dry tap on bone marrow aspiration
  • On bone marrow biopsy- Fried egg appearance

Staining:

  • TRAP
  • B cell markers
  • CD11c, CD25, CD103
  • Annexin A1

questions.text: Famciclovir is a prodrug of _____
questions.solution:
Famciclovir is the diacetyl ester prodrug of 6-deoxy penciclovir and lacks intrinsic antiviral activity.

Mechanism of action:

It is a acyclic guanine nucleoside analogue and is an inhibitor of viral DNA synthesis. In HSV- or VZV-infected cells, penciclovir is phosphorylated initially by viral kinases. Penciclovir triphosphate is a competitive inhibitor of viral DNA polymerase.

Pharmacokinetics:

Oral penciclovir has low (<5%) bioavailability. In contrast, famciclovir is well absorbed orally (bioavailability ~75%).

Adverse effects:

  • Headache, diarrhea, and nausea
  • Urticaria, rash, and hallucinations or confusional states (predominantly in the elderly)

Uses:

  • Herpes labialis
  • Genital herpes
  • Herpes zoster
  • In immunocompetent persons with recurrent orolabial herpes

questions.text: A patient underwent the following procedure for the management of portal hypertension. Which of the following is an early complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedure with the viatorr device. An early complication of the TIPS procedure is metabolic encephalopathy.

The main indication of TIPS is variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. A guidewire is inserted via the internal jugular vein and superior vena cava into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The major complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure >5 mmHg.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a treatment option whereby a percutaneous connection is created within the liver, between the portal and systemic circulations, to reduce portal pressure in patients with complications related to portal hypertension.

Complications of TIPS procedure:

  • Intraoperative complications- capsular hemorrhage
  • Early complication- hepatic encephalopathy
  • Late complication- recurrent variceal bleed
  • Delayed complication- total shunt occlusion

Shunts for portal hypertension:

  • Non-selective shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted
    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt 

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: All are true regarding the physiology of gastrin except _____.

choices.text: G17 is the principal form of gastrin
Gastrin is inactivated in kidney and small intestine
A polypeptide hormone which exhibits both macroheterogeneity and microheterogeneity

questions.solution:
Although postganglionic vagal fibres are parasympathetic, atropine does not inhibit gastrin release.

Gastrin is a hormone that is released by G cells in the antrum of the stomach in response to Gastrin-Releasing Peptide(GRP) or Bombesin. It then reaches the parietal and chief cells to stimulate the production of gastric acid and pepsin. It also has positive trophic action on the growth of mucosa of stomach, small intestine and large intestine.

Gastrin exhibits macroheterogeniety i.e. it occurs in tissues and body fluids as peptide chains of different lenghts.

It also exhibits microheterogeniety i.e. differences in molecular structure due to derivitization of single amino acid residue. Gastrin occurs as three main fragments containing 34, 17 and 14 amino acid residues and hence called G34, G17 and G14 gastrins respectively. Out of these G17 is the the principal form.

Gastrins are inactivated mainly in kidney and small intestine.

questions.text: During your rural posting, a 24-year-old male patient came to you to know about the dietary modification for the prevention of coronary heart disease. According to WHO standards, the dietary goal of saturated fatty acid for an adult male should not be more than:
questions.solution:
According to WHO standards, the dietary goal of saturated fatty acid for an adult male should not be more than 10%.

Dietary modification in the prevention of CHD:

  • Reduction of the fat intake to 15–30% of total energy intake
  • Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake
  • Increase in complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetable fruits, whole grains, and legumes)
  • Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5gm daily or less

questions.solution:
Crista terminalis is not a part of triangle of Koch.

questions.text: Which among the following neuromuscular pedicle is used for reinnervation in vocal cord paralysis?
questions.solution:
Ansa cervicalis with its innervated omohyoid muscle is used for reinnervation of paralysed vocal cords.

Ansa cervicalis is formed by the union of the ventral rami of the first three cervical nerves through two main roots, the superior and inferior. The superior root contains fibers from C1. The inferior root contains fibers from C2-C3 spinal nerves.

Ansa cervicalis innervates all the strap muscles of the neck except thyrohyoid which is innervated by cervical nerve 1 via hypoglossal nerve.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text:
A patient presents with polyuria with a family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma.
He has calcium level of 13 mg/dl and PTH levels of 280 IU/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of hypercalcemia with a family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma giving the suspicion of multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A which includes a triad of medullary thyroid carcinoma, parathyroid adenoma and pheochromocytoma.

Other options: 

Option D: Schmidt syndrome is Type II polyglandular autoimmune syndrome (PGA type II) which consists of Addison's disease, autoimmune thyroid disease, and type 1 diabetes.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Which among the following is correct regarding Clostridium perfringens?
questions.solution:
Clostridium perfringens is a gram positive, anaerobic, motile rod. It produces several toxins like alpha toxin with lecithinase activity.

The alpha toxin of C perfringens is a lecithinase, and its lethal action is proportionate to the rate at which it splits lecithin (an important constituent of cell membranes) to phosphorylcholine and diglyceride. Alpha toxin also aggregates platelets, thereby leading to formation of thrombi in small blood vessels and adding to poor tissue profusion and extending the consequences of anaerobiosis with destruction of viable tissue (gas gangrene).

It can produce gas gangrene, food poisoning and enteritis necroticans.

In invasive clostridial infections, spores reach tissue either by contamination of traumatized areas or from the intestinal tract. The spores germinate at low oxidation reduction potential. Vegetative cells multiply, ferment carbohydrates present in tissue, and produce gas. The distention of tissue and interference with blood supply, together with . the secretion of necrotizing toxins and hyaluronidase, favor the spread of infection.

questions.text: The typical musty odour of phenylketonuria is due to
questions.solution:
Children with phenylketonuria have an unpleasant odor of phenylacetic acid, which has been described as musty or mousey.

Features of phenylketonuria:

  • Due to reduced phenylalanine hydroxylase or tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) cofactor(malignant PKU). Tyrosine becomes essential.
  • reduced phenylalanine → excess phenyl ketones in urine.
  • Findings: intellectual disability, growth retardation, seizures, fair skin, eczema, musty body odor.
  • Treatment: phenylalanine and tyrosine in diet, tetrahydrobiopterin supplementation

questions.text: Negri bodies are not found in which part of CNS?
questions.solution:
Negri bodies of rabies are not found in basal ganglia.

Basal ganglia is involved (inflammation and widespread neuronal degeneration) in rabies. Negri bodies, the pathognomonic microscopic finding, are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites usually devoid of inflammation.

They occur less frequently in cortical and brain stem neurons.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in catalysing the formation of phosphodiester bonds during the repair of the DNA damaged due to reactive oxygen species?
questions.solution:

All DNA repair systems use a ligase to seal breaks in the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA. Although polymerase enzymes make phosphodiester bonds during DNA synthesis, these enzymes do not ligate strands of DNA.

questions.text:
A tall man presents with absent pubic and axillary hair, infantile genitalia, and high LH and FSH levels with XXY karyotype. What is the most probable diagnosis?

LH- Luteinizing hormone, FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is indicative of Klinefelter's syndrome (KS).

KS refers to male hypogonadism occurring when there are 2 or more X chromosomes and 1 or more Y chromosomes. The classic form of KS is associated with a 47 XXY karyotype, which occurs after meiotic nondisjunction of the sex chromosomes during gametogenesis.

KS is characterized by:

  • Small atrophied testes with a small penis
  • Hypogonadism
  • Male infertility
  • Tall stature or increased leg length
  • Gynecomastia
  • Loss of secondary sexual characteristics like a deep voice and male facial and pubic hair distribution

Patients are at risk for type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome (due to increased insulin resistance), congenital cardiac anomalies like mitral valve prolapse, atrial and ventricular septal defects, osteoporosis (due to sex hormone imbalances), breast cancer, and autoimmune diseases like SLE.

Plasma concentrations of FSH, LH, and estradiol are increased and plasma testosterone are decreased.

Other options:

Option A. Vanishing testis syndrome is testicular atrophy occurring due to persistent stimulation by high FSH levels. In severe cases, there is complete regression of the testis; hence, the name, vanishing testis. A normal karyotype (46 XY) is seen in these individuals.

Option C. Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males, occuring due to a trinucleotide expansion mutation in the familial mental retardation 1 gene. The most characteristic physical feature is macro-orchidism, that is, large testicles. They also have a long face with a large mandible and large everted ears.

Option D. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a group of autosomal recessive disorders, most commonly occurring due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This causes a block in steroid production, resulting in increased ACTH secretion and excess androgens. Thus, these patients present with bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, virilism (masculinization in females and precocious puberty in males), and salt wasting syndrome.

questions.text: Tests of statistical significance are all except _____.
questions.solution:
Standard deviation is not a statistical test of significance.

Tests of significance are:

  • Standard error of mean
  • Standard error of proportion
  • Standard error of difference between two means
  • (a)   Standard error of difference between the two proportions, alternatively the Chi Square test can be used for this.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Rate limiting enzyme of ketogenesis is
questions.solution:
HMG Co-A synthase is the rate limiting enzyme in the synthesis of ketone bodies and is present in significant quantities in the liver mitochondria.

HMG Co-A lyase, also an enzyme involved in ketogenesis, breaks HMG Co-A into aceto acetate which is reduced to hydroxy butyrate by the enzyme hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase.

HMG Co-A reductase is an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis which occurs in the cytoplasm.

Related Pearl: Ketogenesis

questions.text: True regarding liraglutide is _____
questions.solution:
Liraglutide is a GLP- 1 receptor agonist.

Liraglutide is a soluble fatty acid-acylated GLP-1 analog. The half-life is approximately 12 hours, permitting once-daily dosing. It is approved in patients with type 2 diabetes who achieve inadequate control with diet and exercise and are receiving concurrent treatment with metformin, sulfonylureas, or thiazolidinediones.

It reduces post-meal hyperglycemia by

  • Increasing glucose mediated insulin release
  • Lowering glucagon levels
  • Slowing gastric emptying
  • Decreasing appetite

It is used in type 2 DM and is the only GLP-1 receptor agonist used in obesity.

questions.text: The volatile inhalational anesthetic agent with the least blood gas partition coefficient is _____.
questions.solution:
Desflurane has the least blood gas partition coefficient.

The solubility of the inhaled anesthetics in blood and tissues is denoted by the partition coefficient. Blood gas partition coefficient is the ratio of solubility of a gas in blood and in the air.

When the blood:gas partition coefficient is low, less amount of anesthetic is dissolved in the blood. Thus the onset of action is rapid.

Blood gas partition coefficient of some agents are:

  • Desflurane- 0.42
  • N2O-0.46
  • Sevoflurane- 0.69
  • Isoflurane-1.46
  • Enflurane- 1.90
  • Halothane- 2.54

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be activated after a carbohydrate-rich meal?
questions.solution:
Only phosphofructokinase 2 will be activated after a meal.

Phosphofructokinase 2 is a bifunctional enzyme that can phosphorylate fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 2,6 bisphosphate during glycolysis. The same enzyme protein is also responsible for its breakdown since it has fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase activity.

When there is an abundant supply of glucose, the concentration of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate increases, stimulating glycolysis by activating phosphofructokinase-1 and inhibiting fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase. 

Other options:

HMG CoA lyase is an enzyme involved in ketogenesis which occurs during the fasting state.

Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis which is favored by glucagon during the fasting state.

Insulin indirectly inhibits β-oxidation by activating acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis) and increasing the malonyl-CoA concentration in the cytoplasm, which inhibits carnitine acyltransferase (Fatty acid oxidation).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about scleredema is false?

choices.text: Mucin accumulation in skeletal muscle and heart
Erythema and peau d’orange appearance of skin

questions.solution:
The epidermis is not involved in scleredema. However, the dermis is involved and is 3-4 times thicker than normal.

Scleredema is symmetrical diffuse progressive non‐pitting swelling and induration of the upper part of the body caused by a thickened dermis and deposition of mucin (skeletal muscle and heart).

Scleredema can be divided into a diabetic and non‐diabetic type. The former is considered the most common type accounting for 25–50% of cases.

The non‐diabetic type is caused by:

  • Post-infective (streptococcal upper respiratory infection, influenza, measles, mumps, dental abscesses)
  • Autoimmune disorders (rheumatoid arthritis, primary biliary cirrhosis, Sjogren syndrome, dermatomyositis, anaphylactoid purpura)
  • Internal malignancies (malignant insulinoma, gallbladder carcinoma, carcinoid tumour, pituitary–adrenocortical neoplasms)

It typically begin on the posterior neck and spread to the upper back, shoulders and scalp.

Erythema and peau d’orange appearance of the skin are observed. The hands and feet are characteristically spared.

Treatment:

First-line

  • Treatment of primary disease
  • Phototherapy with UVA1, PUVA or narrow‐band UVB
  • Physical therapy

Second line

  • Electron‐beam radiotherapy
  • Photopheresis
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin

Third line

  • Immunosuppressive agents

 

Note: Scleredema is not to be confused with scleroderma.

 

Scleredema includes:

• Buschke disease

• Scleredema adultorum of Buschke

• Scleredema adultorum

• Scleredema diabeticorum

questions.text: Loss of interpersonal communication is managed by _____.
questions.solution: When interpersonal communication is lost, check telecommunications can be used to manage the communication.

questions.text: All of the following are component of crush syndrome except _____.
questions.solution:
Bleeding disorder is not a component of crush syndrome.

Instead systemic coagulopathy is seen. This is due to release of procoagulants and inflammatory mediators due to massive crushing of muscles and subsequent reperfusion injury.

Once blood flow is reestablished there is release of massive amounts of myoglobin and vasoactive mediators into the circulation. The total effect of this is:

  • Endothelial damage→ Increased permeability→ Trans-capillary fluid leakage→ Reduction in effective intravascular volume→ Reduced renal perfusion and eventual multiple organ failure.
  • Myoglobinuria leads to renal tubular necrosis.
  • And as mentioned above, systemic coagulopathy.

Note: Alkalinisation of urine increases solubility of acid hematin in urine and aids its excretion. This should be continued till myoglobin is no longer detectable in urine.

questions.text: Which of the following factors increase the rate of cooling of a dead body?

choices.text: Bodies in small, ill ventilated room

questions.solution:
The rate of post-mortem cooling is higher in bodies immersed in running water. 

Bodies in running water show an increased rate of postmortem cooling due to the enhanced heat transfer from the body to the surrounding water. The movement of water accelerates the cooling process by continuously removing warmer water layers adjacent to the body, allowing for more efficient heat loss compared to still water or air. Additionally, the temperature of the running water may be lower than the body temperature, further contributing to rapid cooling.

Factors increasing the rate of postmortem cooling:

  • Body immersed in running water
  • Increased difference in the temperature between the body and the atmosphere
  • Large body surface area
  • Children and old aged people
  • Higher humidity and rapid air velocity

The rate of cooling is decreased in:

  • Excess fat
  • Edema
  • Body covered with clothing
  • Bodies in small, ill-ventilated room
  • Deaths due to asphyxia, lightening, CO2 poisoning

questions.text: Particle with the least linear energy transfer is _____.
questions.solution:
The particle with the least linear energy transfer is beta particle.

Linear energy transfer (LET) is the amount of energy that an ionizing particle transfers to the material traversed per unit distance.

Alpha particles, neutrons and protons have higher LET.

Gamma, X rays and beta rays have lower LET.

Gamma photons and alpha particles have the lowest and the highest LET, respectivey.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient, a known diabetic and hypertensive presents to the OPD. On examination, BP is 148/86 mmHg, pulse 76/min. He is currently on metoprolol for his hypertension. On enquiry, it was found that he is not interested in doing his exercise as advised. The most appropriate next step is _____

choices.text: No modification is needed at this time
Add lisinopril to his current regimen
Add hydrochlorothiazide to his current regimen

questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, the appropriate next step is to add lisinopril to his current regimen.

 ACEIs and ARBs improve insulin action and even ameliorate the adverse effects of diuretics on glucose metabolism. Although the overall impact on the incidence of diabetes is modest, compared with amlodipine (a calcium antagonist), valsartan (an ARB) has been shown to reduce the risk of developing diabetes in high-risk hypertensive patients.

ACEis/ARBS are more effective in lowering BP when combined with other class of drugs

questions.text: Which among the following pharmacologic treatment is most likely given to a 30 year old man with complaints of abdominal cramps, sweating, runny nose, vomiting, and muscle aches? Examination shows that his pulse is rapid and pupils are dilated.
questions.solution:
The above given presentation suggests opioid withdrawal symptoms.

Among the given options clonidine, a centrally acting sympatholytic agent, has  been used for detoxification.

By reducing central sympathetic outflow, clonidine mitigates many of the signs of sympathetic overactivity.

Naloxone is a an opioid antagonist used for treatment of opioid overdose and not opioid withdrawal.

Trazodone and Diazepam has no role in opioid withdrawal treatment.

questions.text: Desmoid tumors are associated with _________.
questions.solution:
Desmoid tumors are associated with colonic polyps.

Desmoid tumor, also known as fibromatosis, aggressive fibromatosis, or desmoid-type fibromatosis, is an uncommon neoplasm that occurs sporadically or as part of an inherited syndrome. It is most notably associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Gardner syndrome, an autosomal dominant syndrome of GI adenomatous polyps or adenocarcinoma, osteomas, and skin and soft tissue tumors.

These tumors arise from fibro-aponeurotic tissue and typically are manifested as a slowly growing mass. They present as firm, non-painful, non-tender masses in the abdominal wall, shoulder, hip and limbs, mesentery, and pelvis. They are also associated with trauma, pregnancy, and oral contraceptive usage.

Magnetic resonance imaging is the preferred modality of imaging for diagnosis.  

Core needle biopsy is required to establish the diagnosis. It reveals well-differentiated bundles of spindle cells with an abundant collagenous matrix. The tumors typically stain positive for β-catenin.

Tumor resection with wide margins is the standard care. Radiation therapy is used as adjuvant therapy after surgical resection.

Tamoxifen and NSAIDs are used as first-line medical therapy. Other systemic treatment options are low-dose chemotherapy, tyrosinase kinase inhibitors, and full-dose chemotherapy. 

Cytotoxic chemotherapy has also been used to treat patients with aggressively growing, symptomatic, or life-threatening desmoid tumors.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: Mechanism of action of alendronate is _____
questions.solution:
Alendronate, a bisphosphonate acts by direct inhibition of bone resorption. Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling, remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled, and then are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Although bisphosphonates prevent hydroxyapatite dissolution, their antiresorptive action is due to direct inhibitory effects on osteoclasts.

questions.text: Which among the following is the Yuzpe method of emergency contraception?

choices.text: Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg stat and after 12 hours
Ethinyl estradiol 0.05 mg + norgestrel 0.5 mg 2 tablets

questions.solution:
Yuzpe method of emergency contraception are combination oral contraceptive containing regimen, i.e Ethinyl estradiol 0.05 mg + norgestrel 0.5 mg 2 tablets. It should be taken within 72 hours of intercourse.

Hormonal contraceptives have different mechanisms of action depending on which day of the menstrual cycle intercourse occurs and which day the tablets are given.

One major mode is inhibition or delay of ovulation. Other suggested mechanisms include

  • endometrial changes that prevent implantation,
  • interference with sperm transport or penetration, and
  • impaired corpus luteum function.

 

Emergency hormonal contraception is not a form of medical abortion. Rather, this method prevents ovulation or implantation. It cannot disrupt a zygote that has implanted.

questions.text: Hypernatremia is not seen in _____
questions.solution:
Polydipsia does not lead to hypernatremia.

Hypernatremia is defined as an increase in the plasma sodium concentration to >145 mmol/L. Hypernatremia is usually the result of a combined water and electrolyte deficit, with losses of water in excess of sodium. Less frequently, the ingestion or iatrogenic administration of excess sodium can be causative, for example after IV administration of excessive hypertonic NaCl or NaHCO3.

Elderly individuals with reduced thirst and/or diminished access to fluids are at the highest risk of developing hypernatremia.

Hypernatremia can develop following the loss of water via both renal and nonrenal routes.

Insensible losses of water may increase in the setting of fever, exercise, heat exposure, severe burns, or mechanical ventilation. Diarrhea is the most common gastrointestinal cause of hypernatremia.

Common causes of renal water loss include osmotic diuresis secondary to hyperglycemia, excess urea, postobstructive diuresis, or mannitol. Hypernatremia due to a water diuresis occurs in central or nephrogenic diabetes insipidus(DI).

 

Polydipsia in a patient with normal renal function will lead to polyuria. And in a patient with impaired renal function will cause hyponatremia due to dilution.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding median nerve injury following wrist laceration?

choices.text: Loss of thumb opposition (opponens pollicis muscle)
Inability to make a complete fist

questions.solution:
Benediction hand is the inability to make a complete fist due to loss of digital flexion of lateral 3 digits. It can be seen in median nerve injury due to supracondylar fracture.

Lesions of median nerve at the wrist present without benediction hand with normal wrist flexion, digital flexion, and pronation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding achondroplasia?

choices.text: Associated ligament laxity can cause kyphosis

questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is a defect  in endochondral ossification of the bones mostly affecting limbs. They are not prone for fractures.

In the lumbar spine, profound lordosis, bulging intervertebral discs, and a narrowed spinal canal are characteristic of achondroplasia.

questions.text: Identify the crystal given below.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts characteristic coffin lid crystals of triple phosphate (ammonium magnesium phosphate) or struvite.

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Oliver’s sign is seen in _____.
questions.solution:
Oliver’s sign is seen in arch of aorta aneurysm.

It is elicited by gently grasping the cricoid cartilage and applying upward pressure while the patient stands with their chin extended upward. Due to the anatomical position of the arch, which overrides the left main bronchus, a tug on the trachea is felt if aneurysm is present. Therefore it is also called tracheal tug sign.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dysphagia and Raynaud's phenomenon since the last year. Recently she has started developing skin induration in her fingers. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dysphagia and Raynaud's phenomenon preceding the skin fibrosis, and the limitation of skin fibrosis to the distal extremities suggest a diagnosis of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The antibody seen in this condition is anti-centromere.

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is broadly divided into two subsets depending on the pattern of the skin involvement and other associated features:

  • Limited cutaneous (also known as CREST syndrome)
  • Diffuse cutaneous

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, Raynaud's phenomenon is seen earlier and is usually more severe and can lead to critical digital ischemia. The skin lesions develop much later, sometimes years after the development of Raynaud's phenomenon. The visceral organ involvement is slowly progressive and often benign. The prominent complications include pulmonary arterial hypertension, Sjogren syndrome, and primary biliary cirrhosis. Some patients with limited cutaneous SSc develop the all characteristic set of features, known as CREST syndrome:

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history

Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent
Auto-antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

anti-RNA polymerase III

 Anti centromere

questions.text: The ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed is called.
questions.solution:
The ultimate desired state towards which objective and resources are directed into is called a goal.

A plan is a blueprint for taking action.

Objective is the planned end point of all activities. It is a precise point.

Whereas, target refers to a discrete activity and permits the concept of degree of achievement.

questions.text: Pyruvate can be converted to all of the following except
questions.solution:
Pyruvate cannot be converted to succinate.

Succinate is an intermediate in the Krebs cycle pathway which can be converted to fumarate catalysed by the enzyme succinate dehydrogenase with the release of FADH2.

Pyruvate can be converted to Acetyl Co A, lactate, oxaloacetate or alanine.

questions.text: While inducing anesthesia in a patient posted for neurosurgery, the consultant advises you to use an anesthetic agent with a lower MAC. The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anesthetic agent is a measure of its:
questions.solution:
The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhalational anesthetic agent is an indicator of its potency. An anesthetic agent with a lower MAC is advised in this patient. The lower the MAC, the higher the potency. 

MAC is an account of the alveolar concentration of the anesthetic that prevents movement in 50% of patients in response to a standardized stimulus such as a surgical incision. It is representative of the partial pressure of the anesthetic in the brain and is helpful in the comparison of the potencies of different agents. MAC is relatively unaffected by species, sex, or duration of anesthesia.

MAC values (expressed as a '%' of 1 atmosphere) of some anesthetic agents are:

  • Halothane - 0.75
  • Isoflurane - 1.2
  • Sevoflurane - 2.0
  • Desflurane - 6.0
  • N2O - 105

Note: N2O is not used alone as a complete anesthetic agent, because of a high MAC. It is generally used in combination with the more potent agents. Such a combination will reduce the requirements of the other agents (65% nitrous oxide decreases the MAC of the volatile anesthetics by approximately 50%).

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)

Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: Each of the following statements concerning endotoxins is correct except:

choices.text: They are less toxic than exotoxins
They are more stable on heating than exotoxins
They bind to specific cell receptors, whereas exotoxins do not
They are part of the bacterial cell wall, whereas exotoxins are not

questions.solution:
Endotoxins don’t bind to specific receptors on cells.

Exotoxins  Endotoxins

Excreted by living cell; high concentrations in liquid medium released on bacterial

Produced by both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria 

Polypeptides with a molecular weight of 10,000–900,000 

Relatively unstable; toxicity often destroyed rapidly by heating at temperatures above 60o 

 

Highly antigenic; stimulate formation of high-titer antitoxin; antitoxin neutralizes toxin

Converted to antigenic, nontoxic toxoids by formalin, acid, heat, and so on; toxoids are used to immunize (eg, tetanus toxoid)

Highly toxic; fatal to animals in microgram quantities or less

Usually bind to specific receptors on cells 

Usually do not produce fever in the host

Frequently controlled by extrachromosomal genes (eg, plasmids)

 

 Integral part of the cell wall of gram-negative bacteria; death and in part during growth; may not need to be released to have biologic activity

Found only in gram-negative bacteria

Lipopolysaccharide complexes; lipid A portion probably responsible for toxicity

Relatively stable; withstand heating at temperatures above 60o for hours without loss of toxicity.

Weakly immunogenic; antibodies are antitoxic and protective; relationship between antibody titers and protection from disease is less clear than with exotoxins.

Not converted to toxoids

Moderately toxic; fatal for animals in tens to hundreds of micrograms

Specific receptors not found on cells

Usually produce fever in the host by release of interleukin-1 and other mediators

 Synthesis directed by chromosomal genes

questions.text: It is called vaccine associated polio paralysis(VAPP) when it occurs _____.
questions.solution:
It is called vaccine associated polio paralysis(VAPP) when it occurs 7-14 days post vaccination.

VAPP is said to occur if:

  • Acute flaccid paralysis occurred 4 to 40 days after receiving OPV and residual weakness lasted for more than 60 days after the onset of paralysis.
  • Isolation of vaccine-related poliovirus in any stool samples and no isolation of wild poliovirus from any stool samples.

questions.text: Cerebral perfusion pressure can be measured using _____
questions.solution:
Cerebral perfusion pressure = Mean arterial pressure - Intracranial pressure

MAP – ICP(or CVP) = CPP.  (CVP is used if it is greater than ICP)

CPP is normally 80–100 mm Hg.

Moreover, because ICP is normally less than 10 mmHg, CPP is primarily dependent on MAP.

CPP<50 mmHg indicates ischemia.

CPP>150 mmHg indicates hyperemia.

questions.text: Shift of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right happens due to _____.
questions.solution:
Acidic pH causes the shift of the oxygen haemoglobin curve to the right.

Right shift of the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve means:

  • The decreased affinity of haemoglobin for oxygen, leading to the liberation of oxygen
  • Increased P50

All other options cause a shift of the curve to left.

questions.text: Russell bodies and Mikulicz cells are seen with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Mikulicz cells- These are seen in subepithelial zone. They are macrophages that show characteristically increased size with foamy cytoplasm and eccentric or central small nucleus.

Russell bodies- These are seen in plasma cells. They are eosinophilic oval shaped bodies formed by secreted immunoglobulins inside the endoplasmic reticulum. Such plasma cells are called Mott cells or thesaurocytes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman came with complaints of milky white discharge with a fishy odour from the vagina and minimum itching. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old woman with a milky white discharge with a fishy odor from the vagina and minimum itching is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. It is treated with metronidazole 400 mg bd for 7 days.

 Metronidazole, an antibiotic with activity against anaerobes but poor activity against lactobacilli, is the drug of choice for the treatment of BV. A dose of 400 mg administered orally twice a day for 7 days should be used or the same can be given as gel, if available.

Other antibiotics that are used include ampicillin 500 mg or cephalosporin 500 mg b.i.d. for 7 days or tetracycline 500 mg four times a day, doxycycline I00 mg twice a day for 10-14 days.  

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by Mobiluncus curtisii, Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. It has a malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge with minimal vulval irritation.

Amsel's Criteria helps diagnose bacterial vaginosis when 3 of the following 4 are present

  • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5
  • Fishy odour of discharge accentuated by adding 10% KOH-Whiff test
  • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy.

Candidiasis is caused by infection with Candida albicans and presents with pruritus, burning, and dysuria with vulvar erythema, edema, and excoriations. A curdy white discharge will be present.

questions.text: Colloid oncotic pressure of capillaries and interstitium is 25mmHg and 5mmHg. Capillary and interstitial hydrostatic pressures are 3mmHg and 0mmHg respectively. Calculate the net filtration pressure.
questions.solution:
The net filtration pressure is 17mmHg.

The net rate of filtration along a capillary depends on a balance of forces called the Starling forces i.e. hydrostatic pressure gradient and oncotic pressure gradient.

 

 

Net filtration pressure = (3-0)-(25-5)= -17mmHg.  

 

Note: The minus sign indicates the direction of filtration i.e. into the capillary.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to Galapagos finches in Darwin’s theory?

choices.text: Invasion of host cells by cancer

questions.solution:
Cancer progression is related to Galapagos finches in Darwin’s theory.

Established tumors evolve genetically during their outgrowth and progression under the pressure of Darwinian selection (survival of the fittest). In the earlier stages of cancer all of the cells in a tumor are genetically identical, being the progeny of a single founding transformed cell.

Following this, there is competition among tumor cells for nutrients and oxygen, and subclones with the capacity to overgrow their predecessors tend to win this Darwinian contest and dominate the tumor mass, only to be dominated in turn by still malignant subclones. This can be used to draw tumor family trees showing genetic relationships of various subclones. Remarkably, subclones within tumors appear to diverge genetically in a fashion that is very similar to the manner in which new species are thought to emerge in complex ecosystems; a cardinal example of the latter are the finches on the Galapagos Islands that inspired Darwin, in part, to propose evolution as the origin of the species.

The image below shows Darwin’s sketch of the evolution of Galapagos finches.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the OPD with a lesion in the anus. He provided a history that he has multiple sexual partners. Biopsy reveals the early stage of squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Radiotherapy followed by wide local excision

questions.solution:
Nigro regimen:

  • The current protocol includes infusional 5-FU with mitomycin C and external beam radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.
  • The inguinal nodes, pelvis, anus, and perineum should be included in the radiation fields.
  • Patients with T2 lesions and residual disease after 45 Gy, T3 or T4 tumors, or node-positive disease are usually treated with an additional 9 to 14 Gy for a total dose of 54 to 59 Gy.
  • Patients with persistent disease up to 6 months after treatment generally require APR. Those who have local recurrence are also recommended for APR.
  • In the setting of isolated inguinal node recurrence, groin dissection is generally required with consideration for radiation therapy to the inguinal node basins if no prior radiotherapy was given.
  • In those patients presenting with anal squamous cell carcinoma in the setting of HIV infection, disease severity (CD4 count and use of antiretroviral therapy) has a significant impact on success of standard chemoradiation.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy presents with normal prothrombin time but prolonged partial thromboplastin time. Mixing the boy’s plasma with normal plasma returns the partial thromboplastin time to normal. questions.solution:
Normal PT with prolonged PTT which returns back to normal on mixing with normal plasma indicates hemophilia which is an X linked recessive disorder.

Deficiency of the enzymes given cause lipid storage diseases. Of these, Fabry disease, caused by a defect in α-galactosidase A, is inherited in an X-linked manner.
