questions.text: All are features of Gerstmann syndrome except _____
questions.solution:
Apractagnosia is not a feature of Gerstmann syndrome.

Gerstmann syndrome:

  • Acalculia (impairment of simple arithmetic)
  • Dysgraphia (impaired writing)
  • Finger anomia (an inability to name individual fingers such as the index and thumb)
  • Right-left confusion (an inability to tell whether a hand, foot, or arm of the patient or examiner is on the right or left side of the body) 

In making this diagnosis, it is important to establish that the finger and left-right naming deficits are not part of a more generalized anomia and that the patient is not otherwise aphasic. When Gerstmann’s syndrome arises acutely and in isolation, it is commonly associated with damage to the inferior parietal lobule (especially the angular gyrus) in the left hemisphere.

 

Apractagnosia is a type of agnosia marked by inability to use objects or perform skilled motor activities, due to lesions in the lower occipital or parietal lobes.

 

Note: Gerstmann- Straussler-Scheinker (GSS) disease is a prion disease and not to be confused with Gerstmann syndrome.

questions.text: Handlebar neuropathy involves injury to which of the following nerves?

choices.text: Palmar cutaneous branch of ulnar nerve

questions.solution: Compression of the ulnar nerve in the pisohamate tunnel (Guyon’s tunnel) is often seen in long distance cyclists who lean with the pisiform pressing on the handlebars.

questions.text: A 45 year old women comes with symptoms of guilt, worthlessness, insomnia, difficulty in concentration and loss of weight for the past month. Which of the following neurologic pathway is implicated as the source of symptoms
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario is suggestive of deppression.

Locus ceruleus pathway starting from the retrolental part of pons is associated with Mood disorders.

Nigrostriatal and mesolimbic pathways are dopaminergic and involved in schizophrenia.

Nucleus accumbens is GABAergic pathway involved in anxiety and Huntingtons disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cardioselective beta blocker with antioxidant property?
questions.solution:
Nebivolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker with additional antioxidant property.

Nebivolol:

  • Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective β1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
  • It stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via β3 receptor agonism
  • Nebivolol is approved for the treatment of hypertension
  • It has potential utility in the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
  • Nebivolol reduces oxidative stress and may have favorable effects on both carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • This can be used in metabolic syndrome.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: A 19 year old male complains of sore throat and fatigue. On examination he had inflamed tonsils with cervical lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. The most likely causal agent is
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of epstein barr virus infection(HHV 4)

It is a dsDNA, enveloped virus with icosahedral capsid.

The major target cell for EBV is the B lymphocyte. EBV initiates infection of B cells by binding to the viral receptor CD21, which is the receptor for the C3d component of complement.

Other options:

ssDNA, naked icosahedral virus : Parvo virus. It infects immature erythroid precursor cells and can cause erythema infectosum(fifth disease), pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis and hydrops fetalis.

dsDNA, naked icosahedral virus : papilloma, polyoma virus

Papillomaviruses cause infections at cutaneous and mucosal sites, sometimes leading to the development of different kinds of warts, including skin warts, plantar warts, flat warts, anogenital warts, laryngeal papillomas, and several cancers, including those of the cervix, vulva, penis and anus, and a subset of head and neck cancers.

Polyoma BK and JC virus infection usually occurs during early childhood. Both viruses may persist in the kidneys and lymphoid tissues of healthy individuals after primary infection and may reactivate when the host’s immune response is impaired.

BK virus causes hemorrhagic cystitis in bone marrow transplant recipients. It is the cause of polyomavirus-associated nephropathy in renal transplant recipients.

JC virus is the cause of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, a fatal brain disease that occurs in some immunocompromised persons, especially those with depressed cell-mediated immunity.

dsDNA, enveloped complex virus : Pox virus

questions.text: A 40 year old patient with complaints of unilateral progressive hearing loss, tinnitus and mild balance problems over the past 8 months is diagnosed to have acoustic neuroma. Which among the following is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: A SISI Score of 80% is seen
Speech audiogram shows roll over curve

questions.solution:
Acoustic neuroma is a retro-cochlear disease and the speech audiogram of this patient will show a rollover curve.

Speech audiogram can be used to differentiate retro-cochlear lesions from cochlear lesions. Roll over phenomenon is the fall in curve rather than maintenance of plateau as seen in the cochlear lesions.

Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, neurilemmoma, or eighth nerve tumor, comprises 80% of all tumors located in the cerebellopontine angle. It is a benign, slow-growing tumor that encapsulates the VIIIth cranial nerve. Bilateral tumors can occur in patients with neurofibromatosis. Speech audiometry typically reveals disproportionately poor speech discrimination compared to the loss of pure tone hearing. A common observation is the "roll-over" phenomenon, where discrimination scores decrease when loudness exceeds a certain threshold.

Different tests to differentiate between cochlear lesions from retro-cochlear lesions : 

Test Type Normal Hearing Cochlear Lesions Retrocochlear Lesions
Pure Tone Audiometry Normal Sensorineural hearing loss Sensorineural hearing loss
Recruitment phenomenon Negative  Present Negative
Roll over phenomenon Negative Negative Present
SISI score 0-15% Above 70% 0-20%
Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) Interval between wave I and V is normal Interval between wave I and V is normal Delayed or absent wave V

Note: A flat curve in the tympanogram indicates fluid in the middle ear.

questions.text: Which is the monoclonal antibody approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The monoclonal antibody approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is sarilumab.

It is an IL-6 receptor antagonist indicated for the treatment of adults with moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis who show inadequate response or intolerance to one or more disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs).

Option A: Durvalumab is an anti PD-L1 antibody approved for metastatic urothelial cancer.

Option C: Nivolumab is a fully human monoclonal IgG4 antibody that blocks the interaction between PD-1 (Programmed cell Death-1) receptor and its ligands.

Option D: Pembrolizumab (formerly called lambrolizumab or MK-3475) is a humanized monoclonal IgG4-κ isotype antibody that blocks the interaction between PD-1 and its ligands. Nivolumab and pembrolizumab are used to treat advanced melanoma.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Lichtenberg figures are pathognomonic for
questions.solution:
Lichtenberg figures are pathognomonic for lightning injury.

These are superficial, thin, tortuous, dendritic red marks in the skin. These marks have a resemblance to the branches of a tree.

They indicate the path taken by the discharge and tend to follow skin creases and the long axis of the body.

Medico - legal aspect: Its recognition may be lifesaving in the unaccompanied comatose patient and it is important because even delayed resuscitation of lightning victims can be very successful.

questions.text: Magistrate's inquest is done in all, except
questions.solution:
Magistrate's inquest is not done in a case of death due to drowning.

A magistrate’s inquest is an inquest conducted by a District Magistrate, Subdivisional Magistrate, and magistrate of the first class rank or any other magistrate as empowered by the State Government, such as Collector, Deputy Collector, or Tehsildar (Executive Magistrates).

Special Magistrate’s inquests are held in cases of:

  • Lock-up deaths
  • Deaths while under police interrogation
  • Deaths in prison
  • Deaths in police custody
  • Deaths due to police firing
  • Exhumation
  • Alleged dowry death
  • In all cases where the police normally conduct inquests, magistrate can hold an additional inquest, or in place of the police inquest.

Note: It is practiced throughout India. However, it is not held routinely but held only on special indications mentioned above. In any case of unnatural death, the magistrate may hold an inquest instead of/ in addition to the police inquest.

Police Inquest: The inquest is held by a police officer (called Investigating Officer) not below the rank of Senior Head Constable. It is practised throughout India.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes capillary leak syndrome?
questions.solution:
Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor(GM CSF) is known to cause capillary leak syndrome.

With prolonged administration, a few patients may develop a capillary leak syndrome, with peripheral edema and pleural and pericardial effusions.

Other drugs causing capillary leak syndrome:

  • IL 2
  • IL 4
  • Clofarabine
  • Denileukin diftitox
  • Gemcitabine

Other options: All of them are Granulocyte-colony stimulating factor analogues and do not cause capillary leak syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is a limitation for a proper sessions court?

choices.text: Can pass death sentence but has to be confirmed by the High Court
Can pass a sentence of imprisonment for 10 years only
Can pass a sentence of imprisonment for 7 years only

questions.solution:
Sessions court can pass a death sentence but it has to be confirmed by the high court.

Sessions Court is the highest judicial tribunal for the district and is located in the district headquarters. The court is presided over by the Sessions Judge, appointed by the High Court. High Court may also appoint Additional Sessions Judges and Assistant Sessions Judges to exercise jurisdiction in the court of sessions. It takes up only the cases of criminal offenses referred by Magistrate’s courts.

Other options -

Options B and C: Courts that cannot pass a death sentence include District courts that deal with civil cases only, Assistant Sessions Court that can pass a sentence of imprisonment up to 10 years and an unlimited fine; and Magistrate courts.

Option D: Magistrate’s courts are criminal courts presided over by the Judicial/ Metropolitan Magistrates. In every district, the State Government after consultation with the High Court may establish as many Courts of Judicial Magistrate as it may consider necessary. There are three classes of Magistrate courts. 

Type of Magistrate Court  Maximum Imprisonment  Maximum Fine
Chief Judicial Magistrate Upto 7 years Unlimited 
First Class Judicial Magistrate Upto 3 years Rs.50,000
Second Class Judicial Magistrate Upto 1 year  Rs. 10,000

questions.text: A 28-year-old was on antitubercular therapy (ATT). Which of the following drugs used in ATT causes anterior uveitis when used in high doses along with clarithromycin?
questions.solution:
Rifabutin causes anterior uveitis when used along with clarithromycin.

Rifamycins are macrocyclic antibiotics used in the treatment of mycobacterial diseases. Three rifamycins described are:

  1. Rifampicin
  2. Rifabutin
  3. Rifapentine

The side effects of rifabutin are:

  • Rash, GI intolerance, neutropenia
  • Uveitis and arthralgias with doses greater than 450 mg daily in combination with clarithromycin or fluconazole.
  • Orange-tan discoloration of skin, urine, feces, saliva, tears, and contact lenses.
  • Unique side effects include polymyalgia, pseudojaundice, and anterior uveitis.

Other Options:

Option A - Ethambutol causes side effects like optic neuritis with loss of red-green vision.

Option C - Rifampicin causes side effects like flu-like symptoms, orange color to urine, sweat, and tears, light chain proteinuria, hepatitis, teratogenicity, rashes, thrombocytopenia, and interstitial nephritis.

Option D - Isoniazid causes side effects like fever, skin rashes, drug-induced lupus, isoniazid-induced hepatitis, and peripheral neuropathy that occurs in slow acetylators.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of borderline personality disorder?

choices.text: Splitting is a major defense mechanism used

questions.solution:
Passive and submissive behavior is not seen in borderline personality disorder but seen in Dependent personality disorder which comes under Cluster C personality disorders.

Borderline personality disorder is characterised by unstable mood and interpersonal relationships, impulsivity, self-mutilation, suicidality and sense of emptiness.

questions.text: Which among the following statement is not true regarding epigenetics?

choices.text: Addition of methyl group to guanine residues
Addition of methyl groups to lysine residues
Acetylation of histone favours active transcription

questions.solution:
The addition of methyl group to guanine residues is not true regarding epigenetics.

It involves the addition of the methyl group to cytosine residues and is known as DNA methylation. It is usually restricted to cytosines. 

The mechanisms and phenotypic changes that occur as a result of secondary modifications of DNA or histones are epigenetics.

Some of them as follows

  • The addition of methyl groups to lysine residues in histone proteins (Option B) is known as histone methylation.

  • Acetylation and deacetylation of lysine residues in histones (option C and D) which favours active transcription and removes acetyl groups from histones respectively.

questions.text: The proximal part right subclavian artery is derived from which aortic arch?
questions.solution:
The proximal part of right subclavian artery is derived from the 4th aortic arch.

On the left it forms the arch of aorta between left common carotid and left subclavian artery. 

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

The following table shows various arterial structures derived from the aortic arches: 

Aortic arches

Arterial Structures

First aortic arches

Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally

Second aortic arches

Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally

Third aortic arches

Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally

Fourth aortic arches

Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery

Left: aortic arch

Fifth aortic arch

Regress completely

Sixth aortic arch

Right: proximal right pulmonary artery

Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

questions.text: Hernia containing sigmoid colon or another viscus as the posterior wall is termed as _____.
questions.solution:
Hernia containing sigmoid colon or another viscus as the posterior wall is termed as hernia-en-glissade. It is another name for sliding hernia.

A sliding hernia occurs when an internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac. The most common viscus involved is the colon or urinary bladder.

The primary danger associated with a sliding hernia is the failure to recognize the visceral component of the hernia sac before injury to the bowel or bladder. The sliding hernia contents are reduced into the peritoneal cavity, and any excess hernia sac is ligated and divided.

After reduction of the hernia the abdominal wall is repaired as in any other hernia.
